           </button>

2013, while managing my traditional family business in Nashik, I was introduced to the world of tech startups and their impact creation stories via YourStory. For people like and around me, YourStory was a single point gateway to learn all things about startups in the early days of India's venture ecosystem. Those stories (eventually) inspired me to start my logistics startup SENDIT in 2015,” writes Darpan Jain, Co-founder of SENDIT."}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"list":"bullet"},"data":"\n\nEveryday my team and I receive such messages from young entrepreneurs on how YourStory was the inspiration for them to start up. How the stories of the trials and triumphs of entrepreneurs gave them the much-needed impetus to take the plunge, if you will, into the wild wild world of entrepreneurship, with all its adventures and wins and risks and rewards. \n\nTo be honest, in an ideal world, these are the messages by which one would measure the success of YourStory’s mission. And even the impact of what we’ve done for the past 13 years and what we continue to do -- stand for the entrepreneur, for the underdogs, for the changemakers, for the innovators, for the problem-solvers… for those who refuse to accept the status quo. To tell their stories. And to tell it well.\n\nIndeed, YourStory has been privileged to have a front-row seat to the rapid evolution and growth of the Indian startup ecosystem. We’ve also been widely recognised for our role in shaping the narrative of the Indian startup ecosystem, having been the very first media platform that began writing about startups at a time when the word ‘startups’ was unheard of in India and entrepreneurship as an occupation looked upon with great peril.\n\nBut over the years, the rapid transformation and growth of India’s tech startup ecosystem and its digital economy have captured the world’s attention, as companies and decision-makers around the world seek to understand the new wave of innovation arising from here. And with that:\nwe saw the need for the country to have an objective news and analysis platform covering the decade’s most important stories at the intersection of entrepreneurship, technology, and policymaking \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"list":"bullet"},"data":"we also heard from many of you -- our readers and our community -- that YourStory needs to now turn its attention In addition, The CapTable will be an optimistic critic of India’s tech and innovation-led ecosystem at a crucial time in its history."}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":"Undoubtedly, startups and digital companies have become strategically important to the Indian economy as it aims to reach $5 trillion in GDP by 2025. behaviour.\n","media":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/b094ec506da611eab285b7ee8106293d/Image2mh7-1616225872839.jpg","thumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/b094ec506da611eab285b7ee8106293d/Image2mh7-1616225872839.jpg","defaultThumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/b094ec506da611eab285b7ee8106293d/Image2mh7-1616225872839.jpg","brandSpotlight":null,"removeAds":null,"sponsoredStory":null,"isRegistrationRequired":false,"timeToRead":5,"tags":[]},"snippets":null,"trailers":null,"path":"/2021/03/swiggy-vivek-sunder-hiring-cxo-evolving-customer-behaviour","featured":true,"mobilePostJson":[{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Through interesting analogies and similes, "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Vivek Sunder, Chief Operating Officer at Swiggy"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":", draws out valuable insights from his vast experience in the FMCG sector for budding entrepreneurs.\n"}},{"contentType":"image","value":{"src":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/e641e900925711e9926177f451727da9/shutterstock1730607304-1594028762169.png","caption":"\u003cp>Image Source: Shutterstock\u003c/p>"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"He believes the presence of both the right and left sides of the brain is equally vital even though our current approach is more of a left-brain focussed. \n\nIn the latest episode of "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"italic":true},"data":"Prime Venture Partners podcast"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":" — a series brought together to help entrepreneurs grow and build their startups with the powerful insights of the makers and doers of the startup ecosystem — Vivek talks to Sanjay Swami, Managing Partner, Prime Venture Partners, "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"on finding the hiring sweet spot and understanding the evolving customer behaviour"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":".    \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"The lure of startups\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":"Vivek says, “The lure of a fast-paced, well-run startup that is blitzscaling or on the precipice of blitzscaling is a very strong one for anybody who has been on the other side. The grass is always greener on the other side.” \n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“You have the skills, but somehow, you are not able to do what your skills can make you believe. So, the gap between actualise potential and real potential, as you look at yourself, is perhaps the reason why the lure exists,” he explains."}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Teachings from P&G\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\""}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"P&G is the best MBA you can have if you don't have an MBA"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":",\" says Vivek. \n\nExplaining the hiring process at a multinational corporation like P&G, he informs that "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"not a single question asked is based on marketing and sales during the five rounds"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":" of the interview process.  \n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"He says, \"They believe if they get people with the right values, the ability to work hard, smart enough to be able to do the analytical work that is needed, they can hone them on the rest.\" "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\"This first principle approach to attacking problems I think is immensely useful in becoming a versatile manager,\" he adds. \n\nFrom his experience at P&G, Vivek advises entrepreneurs to have a 'start with the consumers and work backwards' approach and "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"create a multi-format and multi-cultural environment"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":".   \n\n“Multi-format and multi-cultural abilities is something, I genuinely believe, we will need for business people. You got to work in some places where they practice ecommerce business and some places where they follow traditional trade. You got to work in cultures that are very different across the world,” he says.\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"While hiring a CXO \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":"Vivek advises budding entrepreneurs to not hire if they are not financially and emotionally ready to give up. \n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\"When you are bringing in somebody, who has got the expertise at scale and a different order of experience, you have to be emotionally ready to let the child go,\" says Vivek. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"He adds, \"You have to hire when you want to effect some kind of a change. That change could be reducing the chaos quotient, and increasing the reliability quotient, or scaling to a place that you are not familiar with, which could be a geographic place, a consumer segment place, or a new segment of businesses.\"\n\nVivek advises entrepreneurs to not hire without the right culture fit and without getting the body and the organ ready for the job. While "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"startups should not do premature hiring, they should not also hire too late"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":". \n\n“"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Too late is when a certain sort of rigidity has set in for the company"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":" — not on the 'this is why we have been successful so far,’ but on 'we have tried this stuff and it doesn't work.' This rigidity becomes difficult to deal with for anybody new coming into the company,” he explains.\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Evolving consumer behaviour in India\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":"As one moves from metros in India, the consumers, at large, have a functional understanding and knowledge of English but are more inclined towards the natural script.\n\nVivek advises entrepreneurs not to use the same cluttered format with a lot of English as it would work only for the top 5-10 percent crème of the city and not for the majority of the population. \n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"He says, \"It's not just the vernacular versus non-vernacular difference. It's the simplicity versus the complexity of the UI that you have to think about.\""}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Secondly, these consumers rely heavily on voice notes over text, and founders should think about an interface that takes in these voice notes and gives out the same, which will be better than heavy reading.\n\nHe suggests entrepreneurs to "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"think about how they would interface with these consumers with the language, UI, and format as they go beyond the thin layer of students and digital literates"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":" across these cities. \n\nAnd lastly, he points out that even though there is less money in these smaller cities, the customers are willing to wait a little longer to get a better deal. \n\nVivek says, \"They are bigger value seekers because they have more time, and they are willing to wait. Therefore, they would trade-off this time for getting a better deal.\"  \n\nListen to the podcast "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"link":"https://primevp.in/content/podcast/vivek-sunder-coo-swiggy-hiring-cxos-startups-right-way-winning-consumers-multi-brian-thinking/"},"data":"here"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":".\n"}}],"timeLapsed":"21st barriers","slug":"building-bharat-bihar-entrepreneurs-magtapp","type":"RICH","subtitle":"Mumbai-based startup MagTapp Technologies integrates web browser, document reader, dictionary, and translator to help users learn new languages with the help of visual cues.","publishedAt":"2021-03-21T00:30:00.000Z","updatedAt":"2021-03-21T18:51:21.390Z","brand":{"name":"YourStory","slug":"yourstory","locale":"en_GB","path":"/"},"metadata":{"authors":[{"name":"Rashi Varshney","username":"rashi-varshney","order":0,"path":"/author/rashi-varshney"}],"category":{"id":394,"name":"Startup","slug":"ys-startup","path":"/category/ys-startup"},"excerpt":"Mumbai-based startup MagTapp Technologies integrates web browser, document reader, dictionary, and translator to help users learn new languages with the help of visual cues.","media":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/70651a302d6d11e9aa979329348d4c3e/Imagecrl0-1616144281543.jpg","thumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/70651a302d6d11e9aa979329348d4c3e/Imagecrl0-1616144281543.jpg","defaultThumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/70651a302d6d11e9aa979329348d4c3e/Imagecrl0-1616144281543.jpg","brandSpotlight":null,"removeAds":null,"sponsoredStory":null,"isRegistrationRequired":false,"timeToRead":7,"tags":[]},"snippets":null,"trailers":null,"path":"/2021/03/building-bharat-bihar-entrepreneurs-magtapp","featured":true,"mobilePostJson":[{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"The best solutions are those which come out of addressing a personal pain point, and that is how MagTapp Technologies came into being. Three friends from Bihar felt the language barrier with English and decided to solve the problem for people facing similar issues by letting them search the meaning of words using visuals for easy understanding.\n\nStarted in 2019 by Satyapal Chandra, Rohan Singh, and Abhishek Singh, Mumbai-based MagTapp Technologies provides a web browser with an in-built visual dictionary and document or PDF reader available in 12 Indian languages and 30 global languages. \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Building for billions \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"All three founders were born and brought up in Bihar and faced difficulties with English while growing up. But the turning point came when Satyapal, now 32, was passing through Rasalpur village in Bihar. He noticed that a girl was doing her homework by reading an article online. While reading, she was continuously switching between the browser and dictionary apps. This visual stayed with him, and he discussed it with Rohan and Abhishek. \n\n“From the very first day, I had this idea of a ‘visual meaning of a word that can be seen without switching apps’,” says Satyapal.\n"}},{"contentType":"image","value":{"src":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/70651a302d6d11e9aa979329348d4c3e/CopyofStartupSnapshot17-1616144849386.png"}},{"contentType":"alsoRead","value":{"title":"[Tech30] How a small-town boy from Bihar built a product used at NASA, Uber, and Intel\n","thumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/25e9e0e0605211e984534d4121ad4bb6/800x400-i1-1603518680332.png?fm=png&auto=format&h=100&w=100&crop=entropy&fit=crop","publishedUrl":"https://yourstory.com/2020/10/tech30-deepsource-ycombinator-sanket-saurav"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"All three friends have been serial entrepreneurs. While Satyapal ran his own media company in Mumbai, the brothers – Abhishek and Rohan – were running a product development and digital marketing company, alongside pursuing their studies in Meerut. Abhishek was in Class XII at Army Public School, and Rohan was in the first year at N A S College, Meerut, pursuing Bachelor’s of Commerce.\n\nIn their 12 years of schooling, Rohan and Abhishek studied in 7-8 schools due to their my father's posting in various places. Such exposure to different cultures and languages would help them to build and ideate MagTapp.\n\nSatyapal knew Rohan since the time they worked together on a blog on Facebook. Rohan had also read Satyapal’s authored books, which helped developing a bond. So, they decided to work together as co-founders.\n\n“After Satyapal told me about this problem, I realised I too had been facing it on a day-to-day basis while doing my college assignments,” admits 20-year-old Rohan.\n\nHe came up with the idea of integrating a web browser, document reader, dictionary, and translator into a single app. According to Rohan, most of the time, content is being read online in a web browser, on documents, or on WhatsApp, Facebook, or text messages. \n\n“So, creating an all-in-one app with a multi-purpose feature made sense,” he tells "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true,"italic":true},"data":"YourStory"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":". \n\nBeing a techie, 19-year-old Abhishek created the first prototype of MagTapp. The founders presented it to a few investors and bagged a seed round of Rs 1 crore to start the operation. The app was launched in July 2019.\n\nA big challenge that the startup faced initially, Rohan recalls, was to get good techies. “As a young company, it sometimes gets a little hard to attract a great pool of talent, especially in technology. But we have overcome this by hiring great developers and then training them as per our needs,” he says.\n\n“Our mission is to help billions of people in India and overseas read content in any language seamlessly, without any language barrier. We also want to help 200 million students in India by bridging the language barrier in reading educational and other content, both online and offline,” says Rohan.\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"One-tap solution\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"MagTapp helps users read content by providing them with visual cues. To understand words that are difficult to understand, users can tap on them to get a visual meaning of that word. This functionality does away with the need to search for words in hefty dictionaries or on Google. \n\nMagtapp basically integrates a visual dictionary with a web browser and document reader to facilitate a smooth and distraction-free reading experience. \n"}},{"contentType":"image","value":{"src":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/70651a302d6d11e9aa979329348d4c3e/Image29ka-1616144531114.jpg"}},{"contentType":"alsoRead","value":{"title":"[App Fridays] MagTapp, a made-in-India image browser and document reader, has over 1M users ","thumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/dc9aa1302d6c11e9aa979329348d4c3e/appfriday1-1593600750117.png?fm=png&auto=format&h=100&w=100&crop=entropy&fit=crop","publishedUrl":"https://yourstory.com/2020/07/app-magtapp-made-in-india-image-browser-document-reader"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\nThe startup is recognised by Startup India, and with a team of 105 people, it handles 6 lakh monthly active users (MAUs) on its Android app. It also claims to be the world’s first visual browser, and is going to soon be available on iOS as well as on the web. \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Competition\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":"A 2020 report by WATConsult estimates that 70 percent of internet users access content in Indian languages. There were about 500 million active internet users aged five and above, according to a report released in early 2020 by the Internet & Mobile Association of India (IAMAI) and Nielsen.\n\n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"In terms of web browsing, MagTapp competes with Jio Browser, Opera, and Firefox, and with Oxford, HinKhoj, and Collins when it comes to online dictionaries. But the founders say that the startup stands out because “as a whole, we are not competing with any app but coexisting because we are the only app which provides visual meaning on the go at the time of reading a page,” says Rohan. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\nHe adds that the app integrates web browser, document reading, image dictionary, online book library, online video courses library, translator, and gaming features on one app of the size of 35 MB. Rohan explains this makes the app really light and can be downloaded on any smartphone device.\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Revenue model and business\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"The founders tell that the app has been free for its users, and will continue to be free in the future as well. So, the company reaps its revenue from various sources such as ads, promotion of affiliate products, search engine traffic, and commission on sales. \n\n“We have also introduced an online book library where more than 60,000 free books are available. We are working towards onboarding different content creators on our online library section and selling their content by sharing the revenues,” tells Rohan. \n\nHe says that the MagTapp browser was launched in December 2019 and the image dictionary feature was added in October 2020. Within a short span, the startup has been able to acquire more than two million users. \n\n“We have more than 600,000 Monthly Active Users, and the average usage time by the users on the app is 12 minutes,” tells Rohan.\n\nHe says that at this point, the company is testing various models and is making Rs 1.5-3 lakh in revenues per month. Going forward, it plans to reach the 10 million users mark and generate Rs 1 crore revenue by FY22.\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Funding and future plans\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":"After raising seed capital of Rs 1 crore from angel investor Hasmukh Damji Gala in Mumbai, the startup also raised Rs 2.8 crore in pre-Series A round last year from him. MagTapp is now looking for a Series A funding round to the tune of Rs 10 crore for product development, creating an offline presence, and collaborating with content creators for marketing.\n\n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Rohan shares that some of the product development plans include AI-driven personal assistants called MagBot, which will help the users to learn new skills with MagTapp, and will also give a summary of the content, news briefs, general knowledge etc. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n“We are planning to launch more than 100 skill-based educational games by the end of this year, and will also launch an iOS and a desktop version of MagTapp,” Rohan says.\n\nThe company is eyeing the next billion users, especially those who are first-time smartphone users. “We are solving the language barrier problem for everyone who is using the internet to read,” he signs off.\n\n"}}],"timeLapsed":"21st Mar 2021","publishedDate":"March 21, 2021"},{"id":195404,"title":"[Startup Bharat] Scared of needles during blood tests? For there’s an alternative. Thanks to "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Bhubaneswar-based startup EzeRx"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":" and its unique Made in India, non-invasive device that allows you to get your blood tests done at an affordable price and in record time -- and all without having to draw a single drop of blood.\n"}},{"contentType":"image","value":{"src":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/b094ec506da611eab285b7ee8106293d/imageonline-co-logoadded19-1616079728548.jpg","caption":"\u003cp>\u003cem>[Image Credit: EzeRx]\u003c/em>\u003c/p>"}},{"contentType":"alsoRead","value":{"title":"Startup Bharat: How Wadhwani Venture Fastrack is working with accelerators to catalyse the ecosystem ","thumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/77e43870d62911eaa8e9879653a67226/Imagexxay-1615952406947.jpg?fm=png&auto=format&h=100&w=100&crop=entropy&fit=crop","publishedUrl":"https://yourstory.com/2021/03/startup-bharat-wadhwani-venture-fastrack"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"In a conversation with "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"italic":true},"data":"YourStory "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Founder and CEO "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Shradha Sharma"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":", EzeRx Co-founder "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Partha Pratim Das"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":" demonstrates how the portable device EzeCheck checks for five different blood parameters -- namely haemoglobin, oxygen saturation, bilirubin, creatinine, and blood glucose levels -- just by a patient placing his ring finger on the device. The data for the patient is delivered in 10 to 20 seconds, and each blood test costs Rs 35.\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Watch Partha’s full video interaction with "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true,"italic":true},"data":"YourStory’s "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Shradha Sharma, where she called on ecosystem stakeholders and enablers to support EzeRx through investments and other modes of support. The startup, which was earlier based in Kolkata, is working to make the adoption of preventive healthcare more appealing and accessible for Indians via easy, affordable, diagnostic solutions.\n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“About one out of every 11 adults post the age of 45 are diagnosed with chronic kidney diseases. Almost 80 percent of people over 45 years of age are suffering from diabetes and 2 out of 3 women have low haemoglobin. In addition, almost one million people are being diagnosed with liver problems every year. So these are very big problems in the country and if it can be predicted right at the bottom of the pyramid, it will be a big game-changer in the healthcare sector,” Partha tells \u003cem>YourStory\u003c/em>."}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Partha explained that the EzeCheck device has received the Central Drugs Standard Control Organisation (CDSCO) certification and has an accuracy rate of over 95 percent. EzeRx is now looking to get certifications to expand into international markets.\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Making blood tests a painless experience\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Partha revealed that the blood results can be generated on the "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"EzeRx device that works on spectroscopy, and can be accessed using the mobile app"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":". The report can also be shared within seconds through WhatsApp.\n\nPrior to this, the startup had also "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"developed a non-invasive, non-contact, IoT-enabled portable diagnostic device called AJO"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":" (short for anaemia, jaundice, and oxygen saturation) for testing anaemia, liver, and lung-related health issues. AJO too was designed to make the testing process bloodless and painless as it measured the spectroscopic signal emitting from the conjunctiva, the clear membrane that lines the inside of the eyelids and covers the white of the eye to provide data on one’s haemoglobin, bilirubin, and oxygen saturation.\n\nWhile AJO collects data by scanning the eyes of the users, "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"EzeCheck is another version of the blood parameters testing device which collects data with just a tap of the finger"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":".\n\nEzeCheck is a battery operated device with a capacity of 2500 mAh and "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"can run for 10 to 12 hours"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":". The device is manufactured in India, and all components, save for one which is imported from Japan, are from India.\n\nEarlier, Partha had said, “Nearly 75 percent of our population is from rural India and they believe in curative healthcare approach instead of preventative. And that's a big problem. So, the"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":" idea is to identify the primary health parameters in the early stage"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":", so we can easily predict liver, lungs and kidney problems, or even nutrition problems like anaemia and detect random blood glucose, so that patients can then go in for a complete cure. That's the idea.”\n\nIn a previous interaction with "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"italic":true},"data":"YourStory"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":", Partha had explained that EzeRx has two main business verticals — first, where it "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"provides non-invasive prescreening and diagnostics devices"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":", and second, where it is "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"building teledentistry networks in rural and semi-urban areas"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":". \n\nApart from this, EzeRx also offers an OralOScope solution for detecting oral cancers and pre-cancerous lesions. It also has a teledentistry platform,  Aarogya, to help rural and semi-urban areas get access to quality dental treatments.\n\nPartha says that the EzeCheck device will be available for B2B clients including hospitals, nursing homes, NGOs, CSR organisations "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"under a device-as-a-service (DaaS) model."}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":"\n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“We will not be selling the devices but are operating on the DaaS model. Initially, we are charging around Rs 35,000 and 1500 tests including creatine, blood glucose can be done using the device,” he adds."}},{"contentType":"image","value":{"src":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/a0bad530ce5d11e9a3fb4360e4b9139b/StartupSnapshot-1616084782758.png","caption":"\u003cp>Illustration: YS Design\u003c/p>"}},{"contentType":"alsoRead","value":{"title":"Startup Bharat: Innovation from the hinterland - five inspiring stories from Jharkhand ","thumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/3fb20ae02dc911e9af58c17e6cc3d915/startupbharatfeatureimage-1609306856093.png?fm=png&auto=format&h=100&w=100&crop=entropy&fit=crop","publishedUrl":"https://yourstory.com/2021/03/innovation-five-startups-jharkhand"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"EzeCheck vs AJO\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"While the previous AJO instrument cost around Rs 3 Lakhs, the "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"EzeCheck device is low in cost"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":" thereby attracting attention from clinics and "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"hospitals across Tier 2 and 3 cities, state government bodies, pharma companies, and health insurance companies, among others"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":". He was in the defence services, very disciplined; everything was always on time with him. He was an incredibly charismatic person that people would come and just listen to; he was very, very inspirational,” he says."}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Kunal says if his grandfather was alive today, he would be the person who would have millions of followers on social media. \n\n“I think, most importantly, he inculcated the importance of discipline in my life — being on time for things, not keeping people waiting, being a good listener. But, what if a brand combines the two?\nThat’s exactly what Cornitos is bringing to the table for its consumers.\nTeaming up with Myntra, India’s popular lifestyle brand, and More Retail, a pioneer in","media":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/2d86ed30b28211e8b2e7114aea10c711/800X400-211-1616089746524.png","thumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/2d86ed30b28211e8b2e7114aea10c711/800X400-211-1616089746524.png","defaultThumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/2d86ed30b28211e8b2e7114aea10c711/800X400-211-1616089746524.png","brandSpotlight":{"name":"Cornitos","slug":"cornitos","thumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/images/brandSpotlight/Untitleddesign-2021-03-18T231601-1616089607500.png"},"removeAds":true,"sponsoredStory":true,"isRegistrationRequired":false,"timeToRead":3,"tags":[]},"snippets":null,"trailers":null,"path":"/2021/03/cornitos-teams-myntra-retail-discounts-digital-experience","featured":true,"mobilePostJson":[{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Choosing between discounts and a unique digital experience can be a tough choice for consumers. But, what if a brand combines the two?\n\nThat’s exactly what Cornitos is bringing to the table for its consumers.\n\nTeaming up with Myntra, India’s popular lifestyle brand, and More Retail, a pioneer in organised food and grocery retail in the country, Cornitos maker Greendot Health Foods is looking to deliver a distinctive consumer experience.\n\nIn its just-launched offer, Cornitos’ consumers can avail upto 750 Rs off on a minimum purchase of two products from a select catalog on the Myntra app and website. On buying the special edition Cornitos Myntra offer pack, consumers get to access a QR code printed inside the Cornitos pack. Scanning the code will provide an exclusive coupon code and redirect the consumer to the Myntra website. Customers need to click on the ‘shop now’ tab to open the catalogue where the discounts are applicable. Once customers select the product they wish to purchase, they must enter the coupon code in the apply coupon tab in the cart page to avail the discount. The redemption has been designed to enable easy and direct access to the exclusive discounts. These special edition packs are being sold exclusively at 600+ More Retail store outlets across the country. “The offer provides a first-of-its kind experience to Cornitos’ consumers,” says Shobhit Agarwal, Director Cornitos. In addition to the availability of the packs at More Retail stores, the packs are also available online on the retailer’s portal - "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"link":"https://bit.ly/3lFh5yV"},"data":"shop.cornitos.in/myntra"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":". The offer will continue until June 30, 2021.\n\nMr Vikram Agarwal, MD Cornitos affirms that Greendot’s partnership with Myntra and More is one of the few instances where a F&B brand is collaborating with a lifestyle brand, and a retail chain to drive customer experience. “Most often, brands are focused on profits from minimal investments. This is especially true for F&B brands, which often have thin margins, cut-throat competition and where price wars can have a definitive impact on the sales. But, we wanted to go beyond price wars. We wanted to design a gratification that provides an experience. By engaging with exciting brands outside the F&B sector, we realised we could add a new dimension to our offering.”\n\nWhile this partnership is a first for Cornitos, the brand has been at the forefront of driving digital experiences to connect and engage with customers. For instance, it launched cricket based #MatchCornJeetega campaign and bollywood-themed #CornitosFilmyFlavours.\n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Mr. Shobhit Agarwal, Director Cornitos shares these driving innovative digital experiences are key to enable visibility and a strong brand recall value. This is especially important given that ‘digital’ is where all the action is."}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Setting its base in 2009, in just 10 years, Cornitos grew to capture 60 percent of India’s nachos market, becoming India’s biggest nachos brand by market share. Today, Cornitos is looking to further strengthen its growth. In fact, Cornitos has big plans for 2021 as it looks to expand its product range and production capacity. “We are working towards introducing value-for-money products around healthy snacking,” says Mr. Vikram Agarwal, MD Cornitos. “But, the first to-do list for the year is to drive customer experience that will strengthen our brand value. We want to be known for the experiences and values we offer than just the products alone.”\n\n"}},{"contentType":"divider","value":{}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n"}}],"timeLapsed":"19th Mar 2021","publishedDate":"March 19, 2021"},{"id":195399,"title":"Japanese Unicorn Raksul’s founder on why the company’s globalization strategy is not limited to expanding its geographic footprint\n","slug":"japanese-unicorn-raksul-founder-company-globalization-strategy","type":"RICH","publishedAt":"2021-03-19T02:30:00.000Z","updatedAt":"2021-03-21T18:51:21.390Z","brand":{"name":"YourStory","slug":"yourstory","locale":"en_GB","path":"/"},"metadata":{"authors":[{"name":"Team YS","username":"webmaster","order":0,"path":"/author/webmaster"}],"category":{"id":1650,"name":"Startup Ecosystem","slug":"startup-ecosystem","path":"/category/startup-ecosystem"},"excerpt":"In October 2020, Japanese unicorn Raksul expanded into India by setting up an R&D Center of Excellence (CoE) in Bengaluru. Expanding its geographic footprint beyond its home ground is a significant step for the company. With this move, Raksul became the very first Japanese technology startup to set","media":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/18d4ab20d08111e99775a119527191d8/Untitleddesign38-1616075859281.png","thumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/18d4ab20d08111e99775a119527191d8/Untitleddesign38-1616075859281.png","defaultThumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/18d4ab20d08111e99775a119527191d8/Untitleddesign38-1616075859281.png","brandSpotlight":{"name":"Raksul","slug":"raksul","thumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/images/brandSpotlight/Untitleddesign39-1616080525112.png"},"removeAds":true,"sponsoredStory":true,"isRegistrationRequired":false,"timeToRead":7,"tags":[]},"snippets":null,"trailers":null,"path":"/2021/03/japanese-unicorn-raksul-founder-company-globalization-strategy","featured":true,"mobilePostJson":[{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"In October 2020, Japanese unicorn Raksul expanded into India by setting up an R&D Center of Excellence (CoE) in Bengaluru. Expanding its geographic footprint beyond its home ground is a significant step for the company. With this move, Raksul became the very first Japanese technology startup to set up its R&D center outside of Japan.\n\nA publicly traded company that is listed in the first section of the Tokyo Stock Exchange, Raksul started its journey in 2009 launched its first offering as a listing and facilitating web service which allowed users to look up and compare the prices of various printing services. Although the service very quickly attracted over a million monthly unique visitors, the founder and CEO, Yasukane Matsumoto was keen to reinvent a new customer experience for printing with improved transactions, service quality and product offerings. A printing services digital marketplace was launched in 2013, where Raksul took in customers’ printing orders on its online platform and then matched them to the printing companies for fulfillment, assuming full responsibility for service quality, payment settlement and customer support. The startup worked relentlessly to develop the market by partnering with small, medium and large printers alike, enabling them and getting them on onboard. Having successfully disrupted a complex and traditional industry like printing, Raksul saw the scope to expand into other industries. It ventured into logistics by launching its Hacobell B2B e-commerce platform in 2015 and followed that with the launch of Novasell - a digital marketplace for TV commercials in April 2020.\n\nAfter perfecting its platform-based services model for a decade, Raksul now harbors a global ambition, which Yasukane Matsumoto, Founder and CEO says is at the core of the company's founding vision - ‘Better Systems, Better World.’ The setting up of an R&D Center of Excellence India marks the first step in that direction.\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":3},"data":"Going global amidst a pandemic\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“It was challenging to ensure a seamless setting up of Raksul’s first overseas office because of the pandemic,” shares Matsumoto. “In February last year, during my visit to India and interactions with Zinnov and various tech companies, I met Sanjay Rajasekhar, who today heads Raksul India. But immediately after, the magnitude of the COVID-19 pandemic came to the fore.” By April 2020, the weekly revenue from its printing business had slumped considerably, primarily due to the impact of the pandemic. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Despite the challenges, Raksul saw opportunities to add new digital services and disrupt the markets further. It had, a month earlier, launched Novasell - a digital B2B platform that streamlines purchasing of television commercial broadcasting slots, analyzing and visualizing the effectiveness of client’s television commercials and thereby democratizing access to TV commercials for businesses."}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":"\nSo, it was only natural that the company went ahead with its plan to set up the India Center. “We resumed discussions in June 2020, and we started building the India center soon after”, shares Matsumoto.\n\nWith 11 members already onboard and several more in the pipeline, Raksul India is all set to become a 25-member team soon. Unlike many overseas startups, Raksul India CoE’s role is not just a talent sourcing center. \n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“Given the kind of technology and product development and management talent in India, the India CoE will play a major role in launching and driving the growth for our new, fourth business-line.” says Matsumoto."}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Given that Raksul India has a prominent role to play in driving the company’s globalization efforts and growth as a global digital platform services provider, Matsumoto doesn’t mince words when he says, “Our selection process is straight-forward but stringent. There is a very high emphasis on the company culture and vision,” he says. “It’s a trust-first culture here at Raksul. There is no scope for micromanagement. It’s all about autonomy, ownership and delivery. This is especially important to deliver on our company vision.” And Matsumoto does walk the talk. He met Sanjay only once before launching the Raksul India - a testament to the trust factor.\n\nInterestingly, Raksul has been able to drive its growth with a lean team. The company’s success has been driven by a core belief that it takes only a small number of people to change the world. And this belief has been translated into action multiple times. However, today Raksul is willing to rewrite that rule. “I have always believed that small teams can do a great job. That’s why our team sizes have traditionally been very small. But today as we plan to go global, I also believe that talent is more important than numbers. The right talent can be the force-multiplier to drive exponential growth.”\n\nIn the last 12 years, Raksul’s team, while growing steadily, has remained lean. Currently it has 350 employees, but that is likely to change in the next few years. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"“We want to grow the Raksul India team to 100+ team over the next two years,” he says."}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n"}},{"contentType":"image","value":{"src":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/18d4ab20d08111e99775a119527191d8/Untitleddesign38-1616075859281.png","caption":"\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255); color: rgb(51, 51, 51);\">Yasukane Matsumoto, Founder &amp; CEO, Raksul\u003c/span>\u003c/p>"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":3},"data":"What going global really means for the Japanese unicorn\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":"For Raksul, its globalization strategy is not limited to expanding its operations footprint geographically; it goes deeper than that and operates at two levels. At the outset, it is R&D globalization - which is about bringing global talent and leadership across tech and management. Going further, it is about the ability to tap into the market opportunities with new ideas, products and business lines, globally. The latter is specifically important, considering that the company so far looked at market disruption within Japan.\n\nMatsumoto substantiates why the global opportunity for Raksul is immense. \n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“Raksul has reached amazing success within Japan by leveraging everything local - be it the business opportunity, the talent or the leadership. By leveraging global talent, leadership and ecosystem opportunity, the level of success we can achieve is immense. We are looking to create newer business lines which will not only be positioned to transform the Japanese market but also drive transformation globally because of the relevance of its applicability outside of Japan.”"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"The founder agrees that the globalization goal looks ambitious, especially since the company doesn’t have enough experience in globalization yet, but says, "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"“We have the will.”"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":3},"data":"A broader significance \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"After the brief business slump due to the socio-economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, Raksul’s growth continues to see an upward trend, averaging at 43.4% CAGR across its three key business lines in printing, logistics and television commercials, the launch of its fourth business-line is in full throttle."}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":" While the larger focus will be to continue to drive business growth, the key focus will be on transform and improve by delivering value and not just expanding the business.\n\nMatsumoto also has specific plans for Raksul India. “The first target for the next two years, especially the next couple of months, is to make the Raksul India’s presence felt in Raksul HQ and more importantly in the Japanese ecosystem as a whole.” He shares that while the India team has already begun contributing to this end, with its research and development efforts for the new business-line, it is just a beginning. \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"“The aim is to make the business-line led by the India team as big as Raksul Printing, Hacobell and Novasell.” It is also looking to bring more global leaders onto its executive leadership suite."}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\nMatsumoto’s high hopes for Raksul India have implications beyond the company. Raksul is setting an example for the Japanese startup ecosystem on how they could leverage the talent and business potential of India. In fact, given Japanese government’s increasing focus on digitalization, Raksul’s success in India and Raksul India’s contribution to the company, could play a defining role in further boosting the India-Japan business relationship, especially from a startup ecosystem point of view.\n\nAt this juncture, Matsumoto rewinds a little. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"“In 2018, I was speaking to CEOs and CTOs of successful startups in South Asia and, one question that I encountered invariably was why we hadn’t gone to India yet. Up until that time, no Japanese Internet company had an India office while companies from the likes of Singapore and Indonesia had a branch or at least an R&D center in India. 2018, "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Bastin Gerald"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":" constantly heard friends, "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"link":"https://yourstory.com/tag/saas/"},"data":"who worked in large technology companies"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":", struggling to simplify OKR practices. Short for ‘Objectives and Key Results’, the abbreviation popularised by Intel’s Andy Grove in the 1970s made a dazzling comeback in the mainstream in 2017 because of venture capitalist John Doerr’s book, "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"italic":true},"data":"Measure What Matters"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":".\n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“The practice that molded me at Intel and saved me at Sun Microsystems—that still inspires me today—is called OKRs,” Doerr wrote. “It's a collaborative goal-setting protocol for companies, teams, and individuals.”"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Bastin himself had been a practitioner of OKRs for two decades, and immediately began work on a "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"SaaS platform"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":" that helps enterprises adopt the OKR methodology and measure outcomes. That’s how "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Profit.co"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":" was born.\n\nThe SaaS startup has since built a "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"base of more than 1,100 customers"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":", up from 900 in 2019. It clocks 10 users per customer, on average. “We enable our customers to iterate faster by helping them set stretch targets that are aligned at all levels before guiding and shaping the behaviour of their employees to achieve desired outcomes,\" says Bastin Gerald, Founder of Profit.co.\n"}},{"contentType":"image","value":{"src":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/b3bfb136ab5e11e88691f70342131e20/Profit-1615912928288.png","caption":"\u003cp>Profit.co\u003c/p>"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"The company headquartered in "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Fremont, California"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":", has 20 employees in the US and 65 employees in Bengaluru. Profit.co’s customer LTV (or, lifetime value) is three years. It takes between six and nine months to acquire new customers.\n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\"Traditionally, OKRs have been used in the technology industry, mostly Silicon Valley,” says Bastin. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“In India, the IT services industry has become an enthusiastic adopter. It is seeing leaders actively embrace ‘digital’ and move up the value chain,” he explains. \n\nBut startups still lead the pack to hustle using OKRs because of the framework’s success in Big Tech corporations like Google, Apple, Facebook, Twitter and Amazon.\n\nProfit.co makes the adoption intuitive using software.\n"}},{"contentType":"alsoRead","value":{"title":"This app aims to make meetups easy and convenient by finding equidistant locations\n\n","thumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/b3bfb136ab5e11e88691f70342131e20/Imagecikr-1599891475793.jpg?fm=png&auto=format&h=100&w=100&crop=entropy&fit=crop","publishedUrl":"https://yourstory.com/2020/09/city-square-app-central-location-meetings"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Early years\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Bastin, 49, grew up in Chennai, now the SaaS capital of India. He graduated from the Thiagarajar College of Engineering, and then finished a postgraduate diploma in business analytics from Loyola College Chennai in 1996.\n\nHe started his career as a process consultant, re-engineering business processes for big improvements in performance. His first job was with the TVS Group in Chennai, where he led the re-engineering of the warranty settlement business process, reducing the lead time from 210 days to 7 days. The project propelled the company to receive the prestigious Deming Prize.\n\nHe moved to the US to join Oracle in 1998 and worked on multiple roles implementing ERP software at Fortune 1000 customers and developing product strategy, GTM plans and strategic alliances with partners like Deloitte and Bearing Point. Bastin then studied at the Wharton School of Management at the University of Pennsylvania in 2006, before working at a fintech startup called "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"CashEdge"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":", now part of Fiserv.\n\nAfter leaving CashEdge in 2011, Bastin started his first cloud app venture called "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Apptivo"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":", a mid-market CRM solution that grew to more than 200,000+ customers globally. \n\nOver the years, Bastin had seen both large companies and startups struggle with spreadsheets. And as OKRs returned to the technology zeitgeist, he built the "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"link":"https://www.profit.co/"},"data":"Profit.co"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":" Minimum Viable Product (MVP) and launched it in New York in 2018.\n\nIt counts customers likeMystifly, a Bengaluru-based company that is levelling the playing field for travel agents by providing them with the tools and access to supply of travel inventory, traditionally available to large online players. \n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“Mystifly is using OKRs to improve their performance across the board, increase responsiveness and discover problems early, and do the required course correction using our OKR platform,” Bastin says."}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Technology providers like SunTec Business Solutions are also creating high-performance teams through Profit.co’s OKR as a service. It provides the software, recommended process to implement, training and coaching programs and materials and related services. The Profit.io process to implement OKRs is called PEEL (Plan, Execute, Engage, and Learn).\n"}},{"contentType":"image","value":{"src":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/b3bfb136ab5e11e88691f70342131e20/Bastin-1615912638469.jpg","caption":"\u003cp>Bastin Gerald, Founder, Profit.co\u003c/p>"}},{"contentType":"alsoRead","value":{"title":"This SaaS startup provides supply chain visibility by tracking shipments for SMEs ","thumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/b3bfb136ab5e11e88691f70342131e20/Imageylc3-1582530416723.jpg?fm=png&auto=format&h=100&w=100&crop=entropy&fit=crop","publishedUrl":"https://yourstory.com/2020/02/saas-startup-supply-chain-visibility-eshipz"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Focus on execution\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Profit.co provides options for companies to create goals at various stages: company level, department level, team level and individual level."}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":" Teams can set their goals and align them to the corporate goals, or the level above. “This improves ownership and makes the goals of various teams and individuals clear for everyone, and also how the goals connect to the big picture,\" says Bastin. The product costs only $7 per user per month for smaller startups and has an enterprise sales model.\n\nOnce "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"OKRs"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":" have been set and determined, employees and team leaders check in on the progress. As part of the company's weekly check-ins, managers have their own commentaries that help ensure that the OKR statuses are accurately represented. There is a dashboard feature in the program to help one keep track of what is going on throughout the entire corporation. \n\nUsing this tool, a user can see how each department is performing and how their performance contributes to the overall performance of the organisation. This information can provide the manager with insights on how the OKRs contribute to the bigger picture of managing a team. To break down a company's OKRs, "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Profit.co allows the manager to create individual tasks"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":" that help employees make progress and execute their key results. The manager has the ability to assign tasks too.\n\nThe third part of the cycle, "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Engage"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":", focuses on engaging employees. Profit.co allows the employee to interact with managers, peers and subordinates through an awards system that is based on completion of OKRs.\n\nThe final phase centres on learning. In this section, the manager and employees are able to reflect on their experiences. This gives the employee the opportunity to consider what he or she has "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"link":"https://yourstory.com/2021/01/pivot-and-persist-getnatty-live-video-shopping-saas-startup"},"data":"learned already and where they want to go next"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":".\n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\"Even if you haven’t made progress with your OKRs by the end of your target date, you’ve probably learned a lot over that period of time—like what doesn’t work in helping you achieve your results,” says Bastin. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“Profit.co provides easy ways to document, search and retrieve lessons learnt across teams.\"\n\nIts first customer was a software company providing solutions for the manufacturing industry in the US. In five years, it claims to have disbursed over Rs 1,500 crore across 12+ industries and aims to be profitable in the next 12-15 months. \n","publishedAt":"2021-03-18T23:55:00.000Z","updatedAt":"2021-03-19T16:50:16.906Z","brand":{"name":"YourStory","slug":"yourstory","locale":"en_GB","path":"/"},"metadata":{"authors":[{"name":"Sindhu Kashyaap","username":"sindhu-kashyap","order":0,"path":"/author/sindhu-kashyap"}],"category":{"id":394,"name":"Startup","slug":"ys-startup","path":"/category/ys-startup"},"excerpt":"Indifi is a lending startup focused on the MSME segment. In five years, it claims to have disbursed over Rs 1,500 crore across 12+ industries and aims to be profitable in the next 12-15 months. \n","media":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/e641e900925711e9926177f451727da9/Imagevdhr-1611331044199.jpg","thumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/e641e900925711e9926177f451727da9/Imagevdhr-1611331044199.jpg","defaultThumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/e641e900925711e9926177f451727da9/Imagevdhr-1611331044199.jpg","brandSpotlight":null,"removeAds":null,"sponsoredStory":null,"isRegistrationRequired":false,"timeToRead":8,"tags":[]},"snippets":null,"trailers":null,"path":"/2021/03/lending-startup-indifi-growth-profitability","featured":true,"mobilePostJson":[{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"When Alok Mittal started lending platform Indifi, there was no doubt in his mind that the SME and MSME segment was underserved. \n\nAlok had found that close to 85 percent of SMEs and MSMEs weren’t getting formal credit of any form. Further analysis revealed a whopping $397 billion of unfulfilled credit requirement in the segment. \n\nThis led him to found "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Gurugram-based Indifi in 2015 "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"with Siddharth Mahanot. Since then, the lending startup has disbursed 30,000+ loans across 12+ industries, actively leveraging its extensive network of 20+ lenders, including its in-house NFBC Riviera, and 80+ partners. \n\nThe team claims it has disbursed close to Rs 1,500 crore in loans. The startup "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"link":"https://yourstory.com/2021/03/funding-alert-lending-platform-indifi-debt-financing-indusind-bank-dfc"},"data":"recently raised Rs 35 crore in debt financing "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"from IndusInd Bank Ltd, with a guarantee from US International Development Finance Corporation (DFC). \n\nToday, Indifi is making money on a unit basis on every loan they offer. \n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\u003cb>“As a company we are not yet profitable, but the objective is to be in the next 12 to 15 months,” Alok says. \u003c/b>"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"The team was able to do this by setting unit profitability as one of its early goals, as lending isn’t a lifetime value business. \n\n“Someone who has taken a loan from us will come back to us in the next cycle, but we'll also work with a player. So, we wanted to make sure that every loan is profit making. That was one of the core goals we set in the first two years,” Alok says. \n"}},{"contentType":"image","value":{"src":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/wordpress/2017/07/Indifi-Technologies.jpg","caption":"\u003cp>From left: Indifi Technologies co-founders Siddharth Mahanot (COO), Alok Mittal (CEO) and Sundeep Sahi (CTO).\u003c/p>"}},{"contentType":"alsoRead","value":{"title":"How this fintech lending startup used tech to overcome the serious business challenges of COVID-19 ","thumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/220356402d6d11e9aa979329348d4c3e/Rohit-final-1609767817596.png?fm=png&auto=format&h=100&w=100&crop=entropy&fit=crop","publishedUrl":"https://yourstory.com/2021/01/fintech-online-lending-startup-smartcoin-tech-credit-covid-19"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Focus on three business verticals \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":"A stronger focus on the three business verticals helped Indifi get on track. The first was: could it solve the underwriting problem? The next step was focusing on large marketplaces and partnering with them; this improved scalability. \n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“The third was the supply side model where we don't put all the capital from our own balance sheet. Almost a third of our business today comes from the marketplace construct where other banks and NBFCs lend to our platform,” Alok explains. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":"The founder says the team focused on on-ground execution and relevant market segments, including the service sector and digitally aware businesses, to help streamline and focus. \n\nThe idea was to build a strong data platform to help integrate with several marketplaces and public data sources. It had to be a multi-lender platform so that different lenders could be a part of it, and configure their underwriting criteria and processes. \n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Sandeep Farias, Founder and Managing Partner, Elevar Capital, an investor in Indifi, says, “The founding team had done deep research. The MSME space in India has high growth and reach. They saw it as a risk discrimination problem, to figure out who's creditworthy and who’s not. Because 85 percent of Indian entrepreneurs represent small businesses and can't be unworthy of credit.” "}},{"contentType":"alsoRead","value":{"title":"Why consumer lending startup MoneyTap is eyeing global expansion in the time of COVID-19","thumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/70651a302d6d11e9aa979329348d4c3e/Image8wlo-1598952100947.jpg?fm=png&auto=format&h=100&w=100&crop=entropy&fit=crop","publishedUrl":"https://yourstory.com/2020/09/fintech-startup-moneytap-global-expansion-covid19-renaud-laplanche"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Not his first rodeo\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":"Entrepreneurship isn’t new to Alok. Apart from Indifi, he was the founding board member of Indian Angel Network (IAN) and co-founded JobsAhead, which was acquired by Monster.com.\n\nAlok was looking to return to his entrepreneurial roots while US-based VC firm Canaan Partners was looking to set up its base in India. Caanan brought Alok on board, and he worked with the firm for nine years. \n\nAt Canaan, Alok says he had three ideas that he thought were worth pursuing: lending to SMEs, chronic disease management, and supplementary education. He chose to invest in startups working in the two latter sectors but decided to launch Indifi. \n\n“There was a significant focus on consumer lending but not SME lending. My involvement with internet businesses in India as part of my investment role revealed that every large online platform had deep interactions with small businesses on the supply side. Be it Ola or Uber working with drivers or Flipkart or Amazon working with merchants, the supply side is made of millions of small businesses.” \n\nAlok explains that at one point the narrative was also that online businesses wouldn’t grow or flourish until the supply side saw growth and digital transformation. \n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“I don’t come from a lending background so one of the first things I did was seek out a co-founder. Siddharth had a background in small businesses and was aware of the problems the segment faces. He brought insights on why these segments were underserved in terms of credit, and the innovation that can be brought in the space,” he says. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"His connections on the marketplace side made the transition to entrepreneurship easier for Alok. \n\nIn any lending business, the first questions that crop up are ‘how are you going to distribute?’, ‘how you're going to get customers?’, and others – especially as the conventional model has been brick and mortar. \n\n\"We think that that is one of the reasons why so many people don't get credit…the model is inherently horizontal. If I have a branch, I want to serve everyone in the three and five km radius. In our minds, the way to solve the creditworthiness problem was to go deep in certain industry verticals. We saw online partners as natural partners who could market to their supplier base.” \n"}},{"contentType":"alsoRead","value":{"title":"Why this MSME lending startup believes it can grow big by lending to micro-enterprises","thumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/b3bfb136ab5e11e88691f70342131e20/Imageabnt-1608645883453.jpg?fm=png&auto=format&h=100&w=100&crop=entropy&fit=crop","publishedUrl":"https://yourstory.com/smbstory/msme-lending-startup-aye-finance-micro-enterprise-financing"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Tapping data and tech \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":"Indifi integrates with public data sources like bank statements, bureaus, tax returns, India Stack etc. They also have integrations with 30 spoke integrations with different multicast platforms. Customers and merchants can apply to them, and their data can be shared through those interfaces. All accounting happens through these interfaces. \n\nOn the other side are lenders who can join and configure scorecards on what they want to do on the platform. For not everyone wants access to the entire merchant base. They can use Indifi’s credit models and put in their own criteria.\n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“Their onboarding journeys are configured on a platform. So, if someone wants to do electronic signature versus someone who wants to do field investigation … not all of those different configurations are uploaded onto our platform,” Alok says. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"The first four to five months went in building this version of the platform. Meanwhile, the team signed up four partners on the marketplace side. Apart from access to data, analytics holds the promise to draw insights that improve the quality of credit decisions, thereby reducing credit costs.\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"“Over time, we've gotten better at figuring out which verticals we should go after; where it is that the requirement for our kinds of funds exists. What kind of products to create to mitigate risk and increase approval rate. One of the things that our partners want from us is really high approval rates,” Alok says. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\nAfter three years, Indifi opened other distribution channels instead of just partnerships. “We innovated in creating a marketplace platform where other lenders could come in and lend using our algorithms, rather than only us using our balance sheet, which is a relatively asset-intensive business.” \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"The segment \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Early on, Indifi also focused on building robust security infrastructure. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"The platform has an ISO 27,001 certification on security elements. Sandeep, of Elevar, explains that the team has worked closely in the space, and has complementary skill sets."}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\nThe MSME sector is growing at a fast clip, and its contribution to India’s GDP continues to soar. According to Confederation of Indian Industry (CII), MSMEs contribute 6.11 percent to the manufacturing GDP, 24.63 percent to the GDP from service activities, and 33.4 percent to India's manufacturing output. Despite the huge contribution, the sector is considered laid back.  \n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"link":"https://yourstory.com/smbstory/small-business-msme-lending-credit-loans-lendingkart-moneytap"},"data":"Others in the lending segment "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"include LendingKart, NeoGrowth, Vivriti Capital, Shubh Loans, Happy Loans, KhataBook, and OkCredit. \n\n“The MSME space is large, with several spaces and segments. There are many players but each has a significant offering. What makes Indifi different is the moats they have been able to build,” Sandeep says. \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Take deeper credit risks \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":"Alok explains the pandemic worked as a stress test for their credit algorithms, helping them look at the fault lines and updating them. Another important factor that worked in their favour was that the team looked at the portfolio from a customer level to understand which customers were still in business, which were stressed, and which were out of business. \n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"In lending businesses, this analysis is often done on a full segment level. “We get micro-level data for customers through our partners. This has allowed us to create customer-specific collection and restructuring strategies,” Alok says. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Indifi recently forayed into the pharma segment and will be extending its credit line solution to retailers, especially pharma distributors and local chemists, to help them manage their working capital needs and cash flows. \n\n“We are the only ones who have taken an industry-specific approach to business. Most of our peers have taken a relatively horizontal approach. This is not to suggest that they will not do well; this is only to suggest that within the verticals that we are operating in. We believe that we have solved better for the underwriting and origination challenges,” adds Alok. \n\nIndifi claims to have “four to five percent losses at the moment” and aims to expand into the newer verticals in the near future. The startup, which sells merchandise like t-shirts, caps, and hoodies to corporates and institutes, especially those located in small towns, has now clocked a turnover of Rs 50 lakh, and plans to become the ‘standard’ merchandise retailer in India.\n\nBokaro-based Custkart has completed orders for more than 25 engineering and medical colleges all over India, along with a handful of corporate entities. “Our clients now come from places as far off as Nagaland,” tells Kundan. \n\nAbout choosing Bokaro as the base, Kundan says he always wanted to work in his hometown and village, and create jobs for locals so that they never have to leave their families in search of a job elsewhere.\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Puresh Daily\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Jharkhand is also home to Puresh Daily, a startup that has started a milk revolution in non-metro towns from Ranchi. Manish Piyush, an IIM graduate, who worked in 14 countries in senior positions, came back to his home state Jharkhand to solve a basic problem - access to chemical-free milk.\n\n“People are craving to solve urban problems, but not many are solving some basic problems in India,” says Manish. He joined hands with childhood friend Aditya Kumar to start milk-subscription app ﻿Puresh Daily﻿ Foods in 2019. The startup provides organic cow milk and chemical-free dairy products. In starting the company, the co-founders left cushy jobs, learnt coding, sold software, and also became milkmen to understand the dairy business.\n\nThe duo put in a seed capital of Rs 10-15 lakh, raised from family and friends. To ensure nutritious milk, Puresh Daily grows its own vegetables and herbs on its farm to feed its cows. At present, Puresh has about 80-100 cows, and a team of 40 people. has more than 300 million blue collar workers, and the number is growing as new graduates are added to the workforce every year and agricultural employment drops.\n\nLogistics/delivery, manufacturing, and retail employ the largest number of blue-collar workers in India, who were all adversely affected in the wake of the COVID-19 lockdown. The fact that they lack access to credit – banks don’t reach out to them because of the lack of credit scores - made survival even more difficult. \n\nBut Gurgaon-based fintech startup Bueno Finance aims to change that. \n"}},{"contentType":"image","value":{"src":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/b3bfb136ab5e11e88691f70342131e20/BuenoFinance-1615914728454.png"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Backed by San Francisco-based Y Combinator and Mumbai-based 100X.VC, the startup is a credit building platform for blue collar workers. Started by Sandeep Arora and Saurav Gandhi in Gurgaon, Bueno Finance aims to connect blue collar "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"link":"https://yourstory.com/tag/fintech"},"data":"workers to the mainstream financial world"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":".\n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\"Bueno Finance aims to improve the financial health of the blue-collar segment and is working towards building the credit history of these customers,\" says Saurav Gandhi, Co-founder of Bueno Finance. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"A recent CIBIL study indicates that there are around 120 million households (45 percent of total Indian households) with a yearly income between Rs 2 lakh and Rs 5 lakh. \n\n\"Most of these households are still not part of the formal credit economy as they do not have a credit score, or they are new to credit. The founders have 10-plus years of experience in companies such as American Express, Citi Bank, Capital One, PayU, and Swiggy. \n\nWhen the duo met in 2014, they were leading parallel teams in Citibank. They agreed that there was a huge gap in blue-collar financing. Many workers were receiving money directly into banks, salaries were increasing, but credit had not picked up pace for this segment. \n\nSandeep had seen this problem first-hand while interacting with Swiggy delivery executives during his time at Swiggy. The co-founders had also seen how small credit was very powerful – it played a role in improving creditworthiness of customers and could be super-efficient in acquiring customers. \n\nThis led to the launch of "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Bueno Finance "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":"in 2019.The founders invested Rs 10 lakh in the business and work with their NBFC partners, Stashfin and Liquiloans, to disburse the loans.\n\nBueno Finance has a hybrid approach. A customer can apply for an instant personal loan/credit line that also helps build credit history and get higher ticket loans at lower rates. The customers can avail this loan in their bank account, directly from NBFCs registered by RBI. It focuses on new-to-credit customers (NTC) where it offers small credit to help people build their credit history. \n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"It also ties up with B2B employers that employ gig workers and blue-collar workers, such as Swiggy. This is a multi-functional product; the customer can use it as a credit card or request money in their account like a cash loan. They can transact using UPI in "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"link":"https://yourstory.com/2021/02/bengaluru-fintech-startup-women-financial-empowerment"},"data":"both online and offline world"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":". \n\nBueno provides a UPI handle, which is backed by a credit line approved by Bueno Finance; this can be used to transact at any online merchant. This is really impressive as our Cost to Acquire Customer (CAC) is really low,” Saurav says.\n\nThe fintech startup makes money via the processing fee and interest commission income. \n\n\"Customer education” has been “critical” as establishing trust and the brand are the key components of driving this business. “One of the key issues is financial education.
