","publishedAt":"2021-03-02T23:45:00.000Z","updatedAt":"2021-03-03T01:46:51.532Z","brand":{"name":"YourStory","slug":"yourstory","locale":"en_GB","path":"/"},"metadata":{"authors":[{"name":"Sindhu Kashyaap","username":"sindhu-kashyap","order":0,"path":"/author/sindhu-kashyap"}],"category":{"id":464,"name":"In Depth","slug":"ys-in-depth","path":"/category/ys-in-depth"},"excerpt":"In this week’s Product Roadmap, we feature MoneyTap, the fintech startup that has more than 15 million app downloads, and is constantly innovating to better the credit experience for customers. ","media":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/a9efa9c02dd911e9adc52d913c55075e/PM1-1614692063719.png","thumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/a9efa9c02dd911e9adc52d913c55075e/PM1-1614692063719.png","defaultThumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/a9efa9c02dd911e9adc52d913c55075e/PM1-1614692063719.png","brandSpotlight":null,"removeAds":null,"sponsoredStory":null,"isRegistrationRequired":false,"timeToRead":8,"tags":[]},"snippets":null,"trailers":null,"path":"/2021/03/product-roadmap-fintech-startup-moneytap","featured":true,"mobilePostJson":[{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"In early 2015, Bala Parthasarathy, then part of VC firm Prime Venture Partners, realised that India was at the cusp of a digital transformation. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Consumers were getting familiar with apps and online shopping, but a gap persisted in the financial world. Most banks and NBFCs weren’t catering to the middle-class population that was increasingly going online. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Bala’s research revealed that middle-class borrowers were looking to avail credit without the hassles that were associated with the process. He also realised that most finance companies lacked a customer-oriented approach and did not consider convenience. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n"}},{"contentType":"image","value":{"src":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/a9efa9c02dd911e9adc52d913c55075e/AshutoshDabral-1614692324217.jpg","caption":"\u003cp>\u003cem>Ashutosh Dabral, \u003c/em>\u003cem style=\"color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.84);\">&nbsp;Chief Product Officer, MoneyTap\u003c/em>\u003c/p>"}},{"contentType":"alsoRead","value":{"title":"[Product Roadmap] With over a million orders in a day, how Swiggy uses AI to deliver convenience ","thumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/e641e900925711e9926177f451727da9/shutterstock1730607304-1594028762169.png?fm=png&auto=format&h=100&w=100&crop=entropy&fit=crop","publishedUrl":"https://yourstory.com/2021/02/product-roadmap-foodtech-unicorn-swiggy"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"This pervasive problem led Bala and serial entrepreneurs Anuj Kacker and Kunal Verma to found MoneyTap in 2016. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"The fintech startup aimed to provide flexible, fast, and convenient credit to people, with the help of technology. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"In five years, MoneyTap, now a RBI-registered NBFC, has disbursed over "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Rs 4,400 crore across all its financial products, has a monthly loan disbursement of Rs 200 crore, and more than 15 million app installs across platforms."}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Understanding the market gap"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":" \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Ashutosh Dabral, Chief Product Officer, MoneyTap, "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"says, “We realised that a digital solution that empowered users with flexibility and ease of borrowing, and was a long-term solution was the need of the hour. That's how we came up with India's first app-based credit line. We launched the MoneyTap credit line in partnership with our first bank RBL Bank and have onboarded several NBFCs as capital partners over the years.” "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"India has a huge middle-class population that often needs additional funds to manage unexpected expenses, weddings, travel, education, festive shopping, and more. The need for credit can rise at any time and the credit line product allows people to avail credit whenever they need it, he says. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"MoneyTap charges interest only on the amount availed. Once customers repay EMIs, the credit limit is gets replenished and can be used again. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“It's not just a personal loan or a credit card; it's the best of both worlds,” Ashutosh explains."}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"The team began by building a couple of prototype fintech products to help guide the UX. The idea was to make data-driven UX decisions while using their own hypotheses. They launched their full-fledged chatbot UI, and ensured a good user experience right from v1.0."}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n"}},{"contentType":"alsoRead","value":{"title":"[Product Roadmap] BigHaat’s focus on digitisation led to 5x growth in transactions in the last 24 months ","thumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/a9efa9c02dd911e9adc52d913c55075e/PRM-1613459495490.png?fm=png&auto=format&h=100&w=100&crop=entropy&fit=crop","publishedUrl":"https://yourstory.com/2021/02/product-roadmap-agritech-startup-bighaat-digitisation-focus-growth-agritech"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"The initial product \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"The initial product was built by five engineers in five weeks. “We did alpha testing by setting up kiosks at workplaces and tech parks. Many MoneyTap employees, including engineers, helped pitch the product (cold selling) during this phase (April-May 2016). We then moved to beta testing; the app was downloadable using a beta tester link during May-June 2016). After a few more months of feedback and iteration, we did a full-fledged product launch at the end of September 2016,” Ashutosh recalls. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"The aim was always one: to offer a seamless, hassle-free credit experience. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Once customers download the app, a patent-pending proprietary chatbot takes them through the application process for the credit line. Smart AI and ML algorithms are used to underwrite customers to allow the team to take a credit decision within minutes. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"The team had to create their own smart alternative-scoring process as penetration of credit scores is relatively low in India and there isn’t enough information. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Focus on ‘those with a thin file’\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Ashutosh says the MoneyTap team was able to build models for customers’ application data and other off-application data to build alternative scores. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Having their own alternative-score mechanism helped the team provide approvals to customers who usually wouldn’t be eligible for credit or loans due to “a thin file”. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“We've enabled an end-to-end zero touch process (a 100 percent digital process for KYC, documentation, photo upload, etc.) along with biometric eKYC and KYC via Aadhaar enablement. MoneyTap has also built custom solutions to combat fraud in the system. Our proprietary algorithms ensure that customers are matched to the best product offerings available to them,” Ashutosh says. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":" The team also created complementary products like a routing app for field executives. This ensures that when customers apply for KYC, they will be put in touch with the nearest field executive who will come and collect the documents, ensuring a quicker, better customer experience. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"The team is important, and MoneyTap last year onboarded 30 engineers from colleges such as IITs and NITs, with plans to add 20 more in June 2021. \n"}},{"contentType":"image","value":{"src":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/bd251c602d6a11e9aa979329348d4c3e/MoneyTapCoFounders1-1580203342155.jpg","caption":"\u003cp>\u003cem style=\"color: black; background-color: white;\">&nbsp;MoneyTap Co-founders: Kunal Varma (L), Bala Parthasarathy, and Anuj Kacker\u003c/em>\u003c/p>"}},{"contentType":"alsoRead","value":{"title":"[Product Roadmap] How fintech startup Capital Float is solving lending needs with its in-house technology","thumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/a9efa9c02dd911e9adc52d913c55075e/PRM1-1612857407933.png?fm=png&auto=format&h=100&w=100&crop=entropy&fit=crop","publishedUrl":"https://yourstory.com/2021/02/product-roadmap-fintech-startup-capital-float-sme-lending-in-house-tech"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Understanding the user \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Over time, the team came face to face with a new realisation: they could be building things to improve processes, but it wasn’t necessary that these would be preferred by customers. For example, Aadhaar card scanning wasn't something most users opted for even when given the option. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"New features such as document pickup scheduling, support in Indian languages (Hindi, Tamil, Telugu, Kannada, Marathi, and Gujarati), and more were added based on user feedback. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"This helped improve existing processes and opened up new, untapped audience from Tier II and III cities. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"The team was also quick on the uptake to better the product. The fact that that some customers took time to read and understand the messaging on a particular screen led to the launch of an automated communication that popped up on the screen, asking “Do you need any help?” "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“When we did this, many users, who were earlier leaving because of a lack of understanding of technical finance terms or due to apprehension about sharing financial information, stopped dropping off. We also set up personalised communication to ensure customers didn't delay their payments. This feature prevented users from defaulting or delaying payments on their loans, which would affect their credit score,” Ashutosh says. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"The team had started by launching a co-branded credit card offering with RBL Bank;"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":" more than 175,000 cards have been issued till now."}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“We have created multiple predictive models that raise triggers if a customer segment might turn risky in the future. These models help us predict customer behaviour and allow us to prioritise our efforts and resources,” Ashutosh says. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Focus on innovation \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"A new unit, MoneyTap Labs, was set up to enable the team to keep innovating quickly. This “ startup within a startup” has a small team of engineers, UX/UI experts, and a product manager. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"With MoneyTap Labs, the team aims to experiment and launch different transformative products. “Most fintech products are focused on the transactional or functional aspect, but we want to experiment with interactions – the emotional and cognitive aspect of finance,” Ashutosh says. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"The first of many products from MoneyTap Labs is a foray into expense management via an app called "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"SuperSplit"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":". SuperSplit allows consumers to create groups, add and keep track of shared expenses, send payment reminders, and finally settle payments on the app via UPI. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"The new product launch marks the expansion of MoneyTap’s vision from addressing the lending needs of consumers to exploring other avenues. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":" Other plans that have been in the works for a while now include Buy Now Pay Later (BNPL). The team has already launched partnerships with multiple merchants, so users can get their purchases financed by MoneyTap. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“We are also launching a new BNPL app in Q1, which will allow users to pay later using UPI. Another key partnership is going live that will allow us immediate access to thousands of merchant outlets so users can get their purchases financed at the point of sale. We also have EMI cards /Pay Later cards launching this year,” Ashutosh says. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"The credit market\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"The lending industry now has several players, including Capital Float, EarlySalary, and StashFin. All these startups, which are ensuring credit is easy and hassle-free, have strong loan books and their loan disbursement in an average of five years is between Rs 2,000 crore and Rs 4,000 crore. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"India is clearly a credit-starved nation. A report by ICICI Bank and CRISIL has stated that the retail loan market will touch a whopping Rs 96 trillion by 2020, and will be backed by the government and regulatory support. There will be a strong focus on data analytics and proprietary underwriting methods. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"An analyst at a top consulting firm says we have “just scratched the surface” in terms of lending in India. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“However, COVID-19 has made many of instant loan creditors wary and careful. The RBI moratorium didn’t apply for most short-term loans, but many consumers defaulted. This has brought into focus the need for tighter control on repayment. Disbursals are easy; collections take time,” he says."}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":" The analyst adds that products need to have mechanisms that can check possible defaulters. Most apps currently rely on their own proprietary algorithms. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“Building a deep tech fintech product needs an equally deeper understanding of the space. e-mandis","thumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/5/80396100-2d6d-11e9-aa97-9329348d4c3e/K_(2)1564671114666.png?fm=png&auto=format&h=100&w=100&crop=entropy&fit=crop","publishedUrl":"https://yourstory.com/2020/04/agritech-startup-fixing-food-supply-chain-coronavirus-lockdown"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Learnings startup and taking it global, the founders have"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":" learnings that can aid any first-time entrepreneur"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":".\n\nKrishna recounts the time when he was hiring CropIn’s first employee. “"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"When you hire the first person, you are the HR"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":". You’re sitting in an empty room and telling people that this is [potentially] a billion-dollar company,” he says.\n\nHe goes on to add, “When you sell your product to the first customer, you learn sales. When you sell your vision to investors that you’ll be at $100 million ARR in five years, you learn finance. You learn so much on this phenomenal journey."}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":" I was a tech guy, but I transformed into a sales and customer experience guy"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":" — a journey that may not have been possible at GE [his past organisation].”\n\nCo-founder Kunal weighs in with his learnings — "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"‘talk less, listen more’"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":", especially if you operate in a 100-year-old industry like agriculture.\n\nHe elaborates, “It is a continuous learning journey. This industry talks problems. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"So if you listen in, it gives you an insight into what you have to solve and translate those problems into products and services.”"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":"\n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"The other learning, Kunal says, is to \u003cb>sometimes go overboard with your customers and push for a product to make them see the business impact\u003c/b> it can create. “All our smart agri and climate products got adopted that way,” he says."}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"But perhaps the real learning is in the age-old tip that all successful entrepreneurs swear by: believe in yourself. The rest — capital, people, media attention — will follow."}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":" You just need to believe in the story you are building. Be it agriculture, or sustainable clothing, vegan products, climate change or environmental startups, "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"link":"https://education.yourstory.com/s/store/courses/description/TheFundingCourse?utm_source=ys_article&utm_medium=funding_course_link&utm_content=article4"},"data":"investment funds are now focusing on businesses"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":" that can be built with least impact on the environment. \n\nThe focus on sustainability began sometime in late 2019, but, for obvious reasons, it accelerated in 2020. According to YourStory research data, in 2020, a total of $67.29 million was pumped across 18 deals in energy, waste management and cleantech startups. This year $6.46 million was pumped across five deals. \n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"At the World Economic Forum’s Digital Davos event, Hollywood actor Robert If we ignore the present, we’re going to leave the world in massive disarray. Imagine if one billion people have a mindset of production that does not care, we could leave behind a mess,” says Sandeep Murthy, Partner, Lightbox Ventures. \n\nHe explains that the idea of being good to society and the environment, as well as making a profit, does not have to be mutually exclusive. There needs to be a change in how we look at "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"link":"https://education.yourstory.com/s/store/courses/description/TheFundingCourse?utm_source=ys_article&utm_medium=funding_course_link&utm_content=article4"},"data":"impact funding, as opposed to for-profit funds"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":". And this idea was accelerated by the pandemic. \n\nIn October 2020, Stellaris Venture Partners and IFC announced the launch of a new programme, AI4Biz, to support early-stage AI-focused enterprise SaaS startups. The programme had startups like Prescinto, a SaaS platform, which applies AI on solar power plants to identify causes for underperformance and suggests work orders to plant crew. Blue Sky Analytics, a data intelligence startup, leverages satellite data and AI to generate environmental datasets across a range of air, land, and water parameters.\n\n“Funds across categories are looking at startups that are sustainable, and that doesn’t mean they function with no business models or revenues. The idea is to create a business out of sustainability,” said Prashanth Prakash, Partner, Accel Partners, at a panel discussion at the BHive InvestTech conference. \n\nExplaining how organisations can make a difference, he cited the example of agritech startups with a clear goal of sustainability. The companies in this space explore how supply chains can work differently, and constantly strive towards reduced waste generation on farm produce. \n\nAnup Jain, Managing Partner at Orios Venture Partners, explains “Climate change and its adverse impact is being recognised globally. At Orios, we see an opportunity in the usage of cleaner technologies that helps us eat, commute, cool or warm our surroundings, and entertain or take care of our health in a more responsible and sustainable way, while not taking up the cost too much so that there is widespread and early adoption.” \n"}},{"contentType":"image","value":{"src":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/a9efa9c02dd911e9adc52d913c55075e/sustainability1-1614074135058.png","caption":"\u003cp>Image credit: Shutterstock\u003c/p>"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Sustainability and revenue - not mutually exclusive \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":"How can organisations shift their focus to align impact and growth equally? According to Lightbox Ventures’ Sandeep, the example of Bombay Shirt Company (BSC), the customised clothing brand, is apt. \n\nThe brand fundamentally believes that fast fashion is not helping the environment, and more clothes are being thrown away than ever, leading to overflowing landfills. A BSC shirt is only made when an order is placed, and customers have the option of free lifetime alterations. \n\nAnother example of sustainability and profit working hand-in-hand is the American brand - Patagonia. The brand is known to produce some of the best outdoor gear used by trekkers, mountaineers, adventure sports enthusiasts, and many others. Yvon Chouinard’s company is known as much for its sustainability initiatives as it is for the quality of goods. \n\nThe company had an estimated revenue of $800 million in 2019 according to a Forbes report. The sole owner of the company, Chouinard’s net worth is over $1.2 billion.\n\nIn his book, Let My People Go Surfing, Chouinard says - \n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“I think of Patagonia as an ecosystem, with its vendors and customers as an integral part of that system. A problem anywhere in the system eventually affects the whole, and this gives everyone an overriding responsibility of the health of the whole organism. It also means that anyone, low on the totem pole or high, inside the company or out, can contribute significantly to the health of the company and to the integrity and value of our products.”"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\nThe choices of today will shape our planet tomorrow, and it is easy to imagine the impact of another potential Black Swan event, like the coronavirus pandemic, on people and businesses alike. The food business was negatively impacted amidst the pandemic, but the foodtech and hyperlocal unicorn saw an upswing in terms of delivery.","media":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/e641e900925711e9926177f451727da9/shutterstock1730607304-1594028762169.png","thumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/e641e900925711e9926177f451727da9/shutterstock1730607304-1594028762169.png","defaultThumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/e641e900925711e9926177f451727da9/shutterstock1730607304-1594028762169.png","brandSpotlight":null,"removeAds":null,"sponsoredStory":null,"isRegistrationRequired":false,"timeToRead":11,"tags":[]},"snippets":null,"trailers":null,"path":"/2021/02/product-roadmap-foodtech-unicorn-swiggy","featured":true,"mobilePostJson":[{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"It was a simple value proposition. Could someone get their favourite dish or meal delivered to their doorstep, without any hassle like minimum order value or delivery time? \n\nThis single question led two BITS Pilani graduates, Sriharhsa Majety and Nandan Reddy, and one IIT graduate, Rahul Jaimini, to start foodtech company Swiggy with six delivery partners in 2014. The six delivery partners have now"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":" crossed over 1,30,000 delivery partners (this was 2,20,000 delivery partners before the pandemic). Rahul is no longer operationally a part of Swiggy.  "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\u003cb>Swiggy is now a unicorn in the foodtech space and has gone beyond delivering food; it is now a force to be reckoned with – and the numbers do all the talking.\u003c/b> "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"The company, which began operations in Bengaluru in 2014 expanded to seven major cities between 2015-17, and nine cities by the end of 2017. There was no looking back after that; Swiggy was operational in 50 cities by the end of 2018, 100 cities by March 2019, and 500 cities by December 2019.\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Its new Dunzo-like feature of any delivery anywhere, Genie, is now present in 65 cities; Instamart, the grocery delivery platform, is operational in two cities; and HealthHub, which focuses on health foods, is available in four cities. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"In March 2015"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":", Swiggy was clocking "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"one million orders per month"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"; this touched four million per month by July 2017, 14 million a month in May 2018, 21 million per month in September 2018, and a whopping "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"30 million orders per month in January 2019"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":". \n\nThe pandemic and lockdowns led to a drop in food delivery orders in March 2020, but the additional businesses of "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Genie"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":", and Grocery (now "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Instamart"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":") got in 100 million orders till October 2020. On an average, Swiggy, which competes with Zomato and Dunzo, does about 1.45 million orders in a day. \n\nThe lockdown led many restaurants to permanently shut down due to the sudden drop in dine-ins. However, as the country began unlocking slowly, Swiggy started witnessing a surge in new restaurants. It is currently onboarding 7,000+ restaurants every month with the current count exceeding one lakh.\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Despite their poor financial performance in FY20, owing to the COVID-19 pandemic, the foodtech unicorn has seen close to 6X growth from 2017 to 2019. In fact, funding in the foodtech sector has increased 35X in the same time period. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\nBut in 2014 when the founding trio had conceived the idea, they started by identifying three core problems for any consumer wanting to order food: unreliable deliveries, high minimum order value, and poor restaurant selection. \n"}},{"contentType":"image","value":{"src":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/a9efa9c02dd911e9adc52d913c55075e/SwiggyRoadmap-01-1614083728713.png","caption":"\u003cp>Image credit: Daisy \u003c/p>"}},{"contentType":"alsoRead","value":{"title":"[Product Roadmap] BigHaat’s focus on digitisation led to 5x growth in transactions in the last 24 months ","thumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/a9efa9c02dd911e9adc52d913c55075e/PRM-1613459495490.png?fm=png&auto=format&h=100&w=100&crop=entropy&fit=crop","publishedUrl":"https://yourstory.com/2021/02/product-roadmap-agritech-startup-bighaat-digitisation-focus-growth-agritech"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"An MVP with a focus on convenience \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":"“From 2014 to 2017, Swiggy focused on just one thing - solving for food delivery in different ways,” says Anuj Rathi, VP Product, Growth, and Revenue. He explains they had realised food was a category where demand outstrips supply (delivery partners and restaurants). \n\nIn areas where restaurants were present and demand was high, they began by mapping and predicting demand and ensuring there was available supply of delivery partners to cater to that demand. \n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Swiggy works like a three-way marketplace: consumers, merchants, and delivery. “Most ecommerce plays work on a two-way marketplace model. The complexity for a product like Swiggy comes in because it is all being done real time,” Anuj says.  "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"This means showing consumers the list of restaurants they will be ordering from, the time taken to deliver, and restaurants getting an order notification. \n\n“We didn’t have a separate merchant app or delivery app. We first built the merchant platform and orders would reach the delivery partner through SMS. We had to begin setting up the core systems of the marketplace. For building multiple systems, "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"our core idea was to deliver convenience to the consumer"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":",” he explains. \n\nAnuj says the number of things that have to go right to ensure that a consumer is able to get a product seamlessly delivered is “high”. \n\n“This means ensuring the flow is easy to understand by the consumer, the delivery executive gets the right order, is in the vicinity of the restaurant, and the restaurant partner gets the right order flow.” \n"}},{"contentType":"alsoRead","value":{"title":"[Product Roadmap] From affordable diagnostics to coronavirus tests, how Qure.ai is tapping deep tech ","thumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/a9efa9c02dd911e9adc52d913c55075e/WhatsAppImage2020-03-31at11-1586233172038.jpeg?fm=png&auto=format&h=100&w=100&crop=entropy&fit=crop","publishedUrl":"https://yourstory.com/2020/04/product-roadmap-qure-ai-affordable-diagnostics-coronavirus-tests"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Technology at the core \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Anuj says the team had realised that "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"technology had to be at the core of the business model for operations to run seamlessly and to deliver convenience at scale"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":". Another realisation: they had to operate with their own set of delivery executives. \n\n“We were able to add different verticals as our initial platform was built to bring in that convenience and scale,” says Anuj, explaining that the team had built for the MVP with the assumption that they were high density zones. As the product expanded, the team had to look at the number of delivery partners, restaurants, and the kind of demand in the area. \n\n“Different cities have varied problems, which can be different from where you are starting out from.” \n\nIt was also vital to ensure that many steps in the chain were automated. During expansion to different cities, it was also necessary to "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"focus on price points and the kind of consumers they were targeting"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":". \n\nThe idea was to build a framework around customer needs and patterns in a particular area. It was also "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"important to invest in delivery partners"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":", as they played a key role in ensuring the core proposition of convenience. Other factors that mattered included the place, order flow, number of orders, which restaurant the delivery partner had to go to, and the route to the restaurant. Instructions - carrying the package in a certain way and others – also had to be paid heed to. \n\n“How to connect all these points to make it easier - even for the delivery partner – became essential,” explains Anuj, adding that it is important to work backwards from the consumer demand you are looking to fulfil while thinking about scale and growth. \n\nThe team focused on core food delivery until 2017. \n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"In 2018, Dale Vaz, now the CTO of the company, joined to lead their AI and ML efforts. “We had to work to build tech to manage a scale of over a million orders in a day. From an intelligence perspective, it was largely human-driven and custom-built for food delivery orders,” Dale says. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":"\n\n The team had already had started working on different categories, but COVID accelerated Swiggy’s move into multiple different categories, \n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\"I think we were fortunate that the direction we were in – the ability to provide convenience - helped us prepare for this moment, and we were ready with a multi-category product,” Dale says. "}},{"contentType":"alsoRead","value":{"title":"[Product roadmap] Starting out on WhatsApp, how Dunzo became India’s go-to hyperlocal delivery startup","thumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/a9efa9c02dd911e9adc52d913c55075e/Dunzoproduct-road-map-1581520789482.png?fm=png&auto=format&h=100&w=100&crop=entropy&fit=crop","publishedUrl":"https://yourstory.com/2020/02/product-roadmap-dunzo-whatsapp-hyperlocal-delivery-startup"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Understanding human intelligence \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":"In the early days, if there were extra orders in a location like Koramangala, the operations team would manually assign extra delivery partners to the area. This was done on a dashboard, which delineated areas with more delivery partners and those with fewer. \n\n“When they did that on the app, we had built the system to read that configuration and then immediately reduce the number of restaurants you saw on the app. So as a customer, you may have seen cases where sometimes restaurants just disappeared from the listing,” Dale says. \n\nThis system needed daily and hourly intervention, and necessitated a large call centre that connected with customers, drivers, and restaurant partners. The need for automation was clearly huge. \n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“There was a lot of human activity behind the scenes that needed to be automated,” Dale says. For example if an order was delayed, a notification would be manually sent to the customer service team, which would call the restaurant to know why. If the driver stopped moving, the customer service team would again call the driver. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“Since we were growing and looking to take the product from a single (food) focus to multiple categories, it became critical to rethink the product experience,” Dale says. \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Replicating human intelligence to AI \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"This meant two things - food, a large part of the platform, had to scale with minimum human input, and the other categories also had to grow and scale. \n\nOn the food side, this meant bringing a lot of AI into decision making. But the key thing was: how do you start to incorporate and learn from human intelligence on the ground? And how do you build systems that will replicate and perform that intelligence in an artificial manner? \n\n“For example, trying to control what we call serviceability, which is essentially the number of restaurants that are serviceable, which was controlled by humans to be done automatically. We built systems that now automatically monitor the movements of drivers across the entire network,” Dale says. \n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"A large neural network that tracks drivers moving across India, keeps track of their orders and work assignments was worked on. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"This is an artificial system that is tracking every individual zone and looking at how many orders are coming in, how many drivers are available, what is the work assignment they currently have, and when will they become free. In real time, the system computes how many more orders can they take. This also helps predict what future orders will look like in 30 minutes. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":"\n\nCombining on-ground tracking and the prediction, a decision is made if there needs to be more bandwidth, or if the restaurants have to be made \"unserviceable\" as the system may not be able to fulfil those orders. \n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“Our goal is to make sure that when you place an order, it can be delivered to you. And that's tough in the hyperlocal space, because things are changing in real time. Ecommerce has a physical warehouse and inventory and fixed systems, but with delivery it is real time,” Dale says. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"He gives the example of Genie, saying that it’s where the team has to combine a lot of AI with human intelligence. “A lot is happening on ground in real time. For example, the roads are suddenly dug up, or there’s traffic. This changes the way the system behaves.” \n"}},{"contentType":"image","value":{"src":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/a9efa9c02dd911e9adc52d913c55075e/SwiggyRoadmap-02-1614083771011.png","caption":"\u003cp>Image credit: Daisy\u003c/p>"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"The ‘multi-layered’ AI cake \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":"“What we have done is build an AI stack - a multi-layered cake. Essentially, it is this infrastructure we have built, which is collecting as much information as possible about every interaction, every event happening on our platform. \n\n\"Every time a customer visits the app, every time they click on some menu, we are tracking it to indicate that this customer has some kind of interest in these types of restaurants, this kind of menu,” Dale explains. \n\nSimilarly on the driver’s side, the team tracks where they are moving, the locations they have visited, the number of times orders have been delivered, and cancelled. It does this for restaurants and stores as well. \n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“All this information is flowing in through all our different apps and systems into our data platform, which is processing humongous amounts of information. We process more than a billion events every single day,” Dale says. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":"On top of the data is the intelligence platform, which mines the information. For example, the food intelligence platform is learning how to understand as much as one can about food. If somebody describes a certain thing, what kind of cuisine is it? What kind of food is it? Is it vegetarian or non-vegetarian? Or does it have egg? \n\nThe app also tracks customer preferences based on their order history. This builds a certain persona of the customer - whether they like biryanis or other products, preference for Italian or North Indian cuisine. \n\n“We can also build preferences…whether you like premium restaurants, discounted or friendly restaurants, and other dimensions of customer buying behaviour,” Dale says. \n\nNext comes the applications layer, which is what customers, drivers, and restaurants actually interact with. This is where each customer sees a different listing. For example, the list of restaurants that you see is going to be completely customised to your preferences. Your friends sitting nearby may see a very different list. \n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“Understanding from your past history, your intelligence signals will reveal what kind of products, restaurants, and dishes you like,” Dale says. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"He explains the smart application layer is basically the application stack. From discovery and delivery to back end, fraud, and customer service, all applications are hooked into the smart applications layer, which makes sure the suite product is transformed into an AI-first product. \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Bringing in spatial and time intelligence \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":"The team also added another layer. If you have a propensity of ordering in a certain way in certain locations. From location A, which may be office, you may routinely order easy to eat meals. At home, you may be ordering more family-friendly dinners. \n\nThis layer ensures you will see different restaurants show up based on which location you have selected in your app. This is also true for the time of day. \n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“We recognise both concepts of time and day. In real time, we are changing this. Your weekend list may be different; you may see a very different set of restaurants,” Dale says. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Amidst COVID-19, the team added new features like temperature tracking, hygiene factors, and other elements. \n\n\"From a future perspective, I would say "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"our desire is to really revolutionise the way customers live in India"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":". So when you think about Swiggy, we want to be as close as possible to customers in being able to deliver instant gratification,” Dale says. \n\n"}}],"timeLapsed":"24th Feb 2021","publishedDate":"February 24, 2021"}]},{"type":"content","title":"Inspiration","subtitle":"Stories of people and events that inspire hope, ignite change, and spread positivity","dataAttribute":"inspiration","clickCTA":"/category/inspiration","clickText":"See More","cardType":"RegularHorizontalCard","containerType":"RegularHorizontal","dataAPI":"/api/v2/category/stories/?slug=inspiration&brand=yourstory&limit=12&skipFeatured=true&skipDontShowOnHomepage=true&greedy=true","logo":"https://images.yourstory.com/assets/icons/ic_stories.svg","discoverPath":"/search?category=Inspiration","data":[{"id":194599,"title":"Women of the Pandemic: Namita Thapar says it’s important we do not forget the lessons learnt\n\n\n\n","slug":"women-pandemic-lessons-namita-thapar","type":"RICH","subtitle":"\nOn International Women's Day, HerStory launched the Women of the Pandemic series to honour women who have inspired hope amidst the pandemic by sharing their experiences and learnings from this crisis in their own words. For us in the pharmaceutical sector, being essential commodities, we were at our offices from Day 1 but it was most certainly a new world with new challenges.\n\n These are some of my key learnings during the pandemic:\n \n "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"When you empower people, magic happens -"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":" Our Human Resources, IT teams were incredibly driven, committed and creative in how they managed to get people to work - at 80 percent capacity at factories as well as their homes. Our medical representatives went to thousands of doctors’ homes to deliver PPE kits and N95 masks at a time when there was an acute shortage of these items.\n\n "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Never take anything for granted -"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":" Simple things we did like dine out, watch movies, shop, travel, spend hours with friends seemed like a luxur. We all are going through life overthinking and overworking and this phase made everyone take a step back, breathe, just enjoy and appreciate the little things in life. Many colleagues and friends have admitted that this was the best time of their lives so far - being at home, spending more time with family and doing all the things they had on their to-do list but never got around to. \n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\u003cb>The inherent goodness in people -\u003c/b> Khalil Gibran said, a small act of kindness is worth more than the greatest intention. This period definitely made all of us a bit less cynical and more human. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"On the work front, agility and digitisation were the buzzwords - "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"People had to be creative, make quick calls and rely more on technology to get things done.\n \n Unfortunately this phase was harder on working women than men as they had to deal with the additional burden of online learning for children, no house help and work timings getting blurred which caused not only a burden physical and mental health but also pushed many to withdraw from the workforce.\n\n My 70-year-old father coming to office everyday was exemplary. He started distributing pamphlets on the streets and selling dial-up Internet CDs from door-to-door while pursuing his BCom from Sri Aurobindo College in Delhi University. Later, he pursued his Post Graduation in Marketing from Wigan and Leigh College, Bengaluru. “I guess my father spent all his savings on that,” he says. \n\nDuring college, Lokesh was hustling between three jobs and college.\n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“I was working at McDonald’s -- mopping floors, cleaning toilets, and flipping burgers, and selling CDs in the morning, and performed as a DJ at a local bar by night,” Lokesh says. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Fast forward to 2021, Lokesh is now an internationally acclaimed, self-taught tattoo artist, and founder of tattoo studios chain Devil’s Tattooz. When he was 14-years, Lokesh won the first position in an inter-Asia level painting competition in Japan, organised by Mitsubishi. \n\n“However, I never took drawing seriously,” he adds. \n\nIn college, while juggling between classes and three jobs, Lokesh tried his hands at tattoo art during the weekends. “I was fascinated by tattoos. I saved a few thousand rupees and bought a tattoo machine, without knowing how to put the needle in the machine,” he says. \n\nLokesh tried his first tattoo on his retired Army soldier father. “I was always into drawing skulls and crossbones. I did a big demon on his arms, using a single needle...It turned out to be good and is still holding strong,” he says. \n\nThe second and third, he did on his own body. Soon, Lokesh started trying tattoos on his friends, and “It was the only thing that I did not do for money...In fact, I was ready to pay them (friends) money to get tattooed by me,” Lokesh quips.\n"}},{"contentType":"image","value":{"src":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/7/3fb20ae02dc911e9af58c17e6cc3d915/Devilztattooz-1615552797382.jpg","caption":"\u003cp>\u003cem>A tattoo done by Lokesh\u003c/em>\u003c/p>"}},{"contentType":"alsoRead","value":{"title":"Teaching the art of tattooing to acid attack victims, Vikas Malani’s body of work breaks stereotypes","thumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/wordpress/2017/10/yourstory-Vikas-Malani-Chhanv.jpg?fm=png&auto=format&h=100&w=100&crop=entropy&fit=crop","publishedUrl":"https://yourstory.com/2017/10/vikas-malani-tattooing"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Most of the equipment had to be imported, and once Lokesh ran out of supplies, he started charging people a little to buy the basic supplies. By 2003, friends of friends and acquaintances started lining up to get tattooed. At that time, there were hardly any tattoo studios in Delhi, and Lokesh set up his work place in a friend’s house, and later moved to a small salon in Vasant Vihar, Delhi. \n\nFrom doing five tattoos a month, he soon escalated to do "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"15 tattoos every day"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":". “My passion started turning into a profession. The same year, he opened the first Devil’z Tattooz store in Greater Kailash, Delhi, followed by one in Gurugram in 2013, and recently another at Dwarka. Today, a team of 16 artists work under Lokesh, and he has the biggest team of female tattoo artists in India. \n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"He holds a \u003cem>Guinness World Record \u003c/em>with his team for tattooing the maximum number of flags on a human body. "}},{"contentType":"image","value":{"src":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/7/3fb20ae02dc911e9af58c17e6cc3d915/IshantSharma-1615553080390.jpg","caption":"\u003cp>\u003cem>Lokesh along with his client and cricketer Ishant Sharma \u003c/em>\u003c/p>"}},{"contentType":"alsoRead","value":{"title":"A world map of wisdom: How a Dehradun boy is sharing life lessons with real-life stories from across 195 countries","thumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/7/3fb20ae02dc911e9af58c17e6cc3d915/Image22wf-1614791397723.jpg?fm=png&auto=format&h=100&w=100&crop=entropy&fit=crop","publishedUrl":"https://yourstory.com/weekender/world-wisdom-map-deepak-ramola-project-fuel"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Going places \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"In 2010, Lokesh was extensively travelling to the USA and Europe, perfecting his art in some of the top-rated studios in the world including Paul Booth’s"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"italic":true},"data":" Last Rites Tattoo Gallery "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"in New York City; Tattooing has become mainstream, however, the profession itself is not popularly seen as a career choice,” he says. \n\nLokesh suggests that one should never get a tattoo done according to what is trending. They are taking on laborious, arduous jobs with grace and dignity, with a purpose of fulfilling their career aims and also contributing to their family income.\n\nWhen you think butcher, you automatically picture a man standing behind the counter as you choose your choicest pieces of fish or meats. The cutting, cleaning and packing is not a very easy task, often involving physical labour and long hours.\n\nHowever, these women at different outlets of TenderCuts, an omnichannel meat and seafood brand, are breaking the norm in many ways. They have taken up jobs as butchers, working diligently alongside men as they work different shifts, sometimes signing in as early as 5.30 in the morning. Their job entails standing at their stations for a long period of time as they go about their different tasks.\n\nThese women are not complaining. They are proud to be women butchers, for they believe any job comes with its own dignity. They are also happy to be earning and taking care of their families.\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true,"italic":true},"data":"HerStory"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":" spoke to "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Sudarvani, Chinna Ponnu and Hajeera "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"from different TenderCuts outlets in Chennai to understand what it means to break a stereotype and cut across barriers, literally.\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Sudarvani\n"}},{"contentType":"image","value":{"src":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/4/8e7cc4102d6c11e9aa979329348d4c3e/sudarvani2-1615373787059.jpg"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Thirty-four-year-old "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Sudarvani"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":" works as a butcher at TenderCuts’ at Thoraipakkam outlet in Chennai. She says she was proud to be known as the “butcher’s daughter”. She got married after two years to a relative. work.\n\n","media":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/4/8e7cc4102d6c11e9aa979329348d4c3e/Imageq2k8-1615205315604.jpg","thumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/4/8e7cc4102d6c11e9aa979329348d4c3e/Imageq2k8-1615205315604.jpg","defaultThumbnail":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/4/8e7cc4102d6c11e9aa979329348d4c3e/Imageq2k8-1615205315604.jpg","brandSpotlight":null,"removeAds":null,"sponsoredStory":null,"isRegistrationRequired":false,"timeToRead":4,"tags":[]},"snippets":null,"trailers":null,"path":"/herstory/2021/03/india-first-woman-truck-driver-yogita-raghuvanshi-shell-campaign","featured":true,"mobilePostJson":[{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Yogita Raghuvanshi "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"is well-known as India’s first woman truck driver. A qualified lawyer, she preferred the tough life on the highways to look after her family.\n"}},{"contentType":"image","value":{"src":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/4/8e7cc4102d6c11e9aa979329348d4c3e/Image5srb-1615206078386.jpg"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Her story is one of grit, determination and resilience. Yogita grew up in "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Nandurbar in Maharashtra "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":"with four siblings, earning degrees in Commerce and Law. She was happy being a wife and a mother when her husband encouraged her to study law. When her husband died 16 years ago, she preferred to rough it out on the road than practice law.\n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Yogita’s explanation is practical. She says, “If I had opted to be a junior to some lawyer and enter the legal profession, I would have got only a pittance for the many initial years. But I learnt that driving trucks meant instant wages and greater stability. In a country that is developing at such a rapid pace, there will always be work for a truck driver.”"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Her children, Yashika and Yashwin were young, and she had to support her family. “We had employed a driver, but I was making losses because of that. So, I decided to take the matters in my own hands, changed the course of my life from losses to profitability and realised that "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"Great Things Happen When You Move."}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"”\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Strength of a woman\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":"Yogita is alluding to Shell India’ Great Things Happen When You Move campaign that she is a part of. The campaign celebrates the indomitable spirit of Indians, their dreams, and aspirations along with their inspiring journey.\n\nYogita’s first trip was from Bhopal to Ahmedabad. “It was new for me, but I was prepared for it. I trusted my instincts and my confidence. I didn’t even know the roads or which road leads to which highway. I kept asking people for directions and kept moving ahead towards my destination,” she says.\n\nYogita is far from the archetypal inter-state trucker. She says she never considers a challenge as a challenge.\n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“I had made up my mind that I just want to move forward with my life and do this for myself and my family. I kept moving forward, breaking all barriers and here I am today. Everything is possible once you start, and you can fulfill all your aspirations when you believe this,” she adds."}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Also, she never pays much attention to people’s comments. \n\n“I love what I do but shuttling between cities across the country with my truck had its inevitable load of problems. Nobody believes that I drive trucks – whether then or now. They assume that I am the driver’s woman. Mechanics on the highway, men at "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"italic":true},"data":"dhabas"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":" and elsewhere leer at me, but when they see me at the wheel, their look changes dramatically. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"data":"However, she chose to ignore them and move ahead.\n\nWhile there may not be many women on the road, Yogita says it’s heartening that they are coming forward and taking up this job. \n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“All I want to tell them is that one must have self-belief and must not succumb to what the world perceives about them. If we want, we can do anything and break social stereotypes. I feel extremely powerful behind this wheel and I am proud to have taken up a job that is remotely associated with women. I love to take challenges head on every day in my field of work, and this gives me a lot of confidence,” she says."}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\nWhile driving by villages, Yogita says she sees children waiting outside the locked gates of schools that have stopped functioning.\n\n“It is a despairing sight. I plan to teach these children when I am done with trucking,” she adds.\n"}}],"timeLapsed":"9th Mar 2021","publishedDate":"March 09, 2021"},{"id":193816,"title":"Women’s Day: Women entrepreneurs on gender biases and how they overcame them\n\n","slug":"womens-day-gender-bias-overcoming-challenge","type":"RICH","subtitle":"What are the biases women face? And how do they overcome them? "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true,"italic":true},"data":"HerStory"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":" spoke to a cross-section of women to understand how they faced biases – both conscious and unconscious, and how they overcame them.\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Onward with zeal and passion\n"}},{"contentType":"image","value":{"src":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/4/8e7cc4102d6c11e9aa979329348d4c3e/Untitleddesign62-1615264106877.png"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"An industry that has male-dominated "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"tailors, "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true,"italic":true},"data":"karigars"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":", and vendors"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":" is not particularly considered something a woman can master, and the bias about a woman running and regulating a manufacturing unit wasn’t so accepting and forthcoming by some of our vendors. Inexperience initially was a baggage too, however, we had our way to turn the tables around with not just our negotiation skills and thorough market research but also our zeal and passion helped us storm through the passage eventually making it more open and accepting of women being in charge.\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true,"italic":true},"data":"Ankita Bansal & Gayatri Bansal, Shopify Merchants and Co-founders - THERE!"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Versatility of emotions\n"}},{"contentType":"image","value":{"src":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/4/8e7cc4102d6c11e9aa979329348d4c3e/Imageutvy-1615199555209.jpg"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"The oldest bias in the book is that our society is conditioned to think women are soft and feminine and men are aggressive and masculine. Being in the field of law as a woman who speaks her mind, it can get tough to make people listen to you with an open mind. In fact, the higher you go, the tougher it gets. Truth is that femininity and masculinity are characteristics that serve well given their right use and these are available to all genders, should they so choose to harness. For instance, when it comes to managerial roles, various industry intelligence now realises that empathy is as critical, if not more, as taking tough calls. Being a manager is about versatility of emotions, understanding, and actions you can take. \n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true,"italic":true},"data":"Archana Khosla Burman, Founder Partner - Vertices Partners "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Chose to fight back\n"}},{"contentType":"image","value":{"src":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/4/8e7cc4102d6c11e9aa979329348d4c3e/Imagez2vw-1615199686844.jpg"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"While urbanisation and literacy rates have increased and have lifted the social status of women in the Indian society, economic inclusion still remains fairly low. My initial years as a woman entrepreneur leading the organisation were tough. Being the only woman in a room full of startup founders who were men used to rattle me sometimes. I chose to fight back all the underlying prejudices based on gender and break the glass ceiling one step at a time. The most important lesson that 2020 has taught us is to come together as a global community and fight for a more inclusive and progressive society to make a ‘Real Change’. We have experienced a global pandemic and time is of the essence to start working together.  \n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true,"italic":true},"data":"Sneha Choudhry, CBO & Co-founder - Zolostays"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Change the status quo\n"}},{"contentType":"image","value":{"src":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/4/8e7cc4102d6c11e9aa979329348d4c3e/Imagex2dd-1615199751591.jpg"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"The world we live in today is no longer just a man's world. Women from all walks of life have fought some fierce battles against this idea of male dominance and supremacy. The case of a woman entrepreneur is no different. Traditionally associated with stereotypical roles of managing households, women are sadly seldom seen as entrepreneurs - a testament to this is the glaring difference in gender ratio amongst entrepreneurs in India. While things are getting better with time, no way are we close to equity. Let’s hope that we are able to set an example for the coming generations and inspire them to change the status quo.\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true,"italic":true},"data":"Deepshikha Kumar, Founder & CEO - SpeakIn"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"My numbers speak for me\n"}},{"contentType":"image","value":{"src":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/4/8e7cc4102d6c11e9aa979329348d4c3e/AnkitaJainCo-founderCEOGoPaisa-1615199782077.png"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"At 23, when I stepped into the industry with GoPaisa, a woman in tech was still not a common idea. It raised many eyebrows. Round the table, in conferences and brand meetings, often I would be the only woman. I would not get heard enough, leading to a lack of opportunities for me. And what I understand is that it was not intentional. It was just there like something obvious or natural, which is sad. But all of this never made me question my abilities, and only made me more tenacious and persistent. Today, all the biases have evaporated, and my numbers speak for me.\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true,"italic":true},"data":"Ankita Jain, Co-founder and Marketing Head - GoPaisa."}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Breaking tradition\n"}},{"contentType":"image","value":{"src":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/4/8e7cc4102d6c11e9aa979329348d4c3e/PoojaShethphoto-1615199831639.jpeg"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\nEstablishing a differentiated product category for eco-friendly and sustainable lab-grown diamonds in an industry otherwise dominated by the conventional mined diamonds ingrained in the legacy of jewellery has been the greatest challenge to overcome.\n\nTalking about breaking tradition - not coming from a jewellery family - has held me in good stead and allowed me to present an independent, unbiased perspective on these non-mined diamonds as well as advocate its authenticity, the underlying indigenous technology and the ecological benefits to the increasingly evolving and environmentally conscious consumer. \n\nPassion, hustle, and focus is helping me break barriers in this male dominated industry.\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true,"italic":true},"data":"Pooja Sheth, Founder - Limelight Lab Grown Diamonds "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Stay calm and driven\n"}},{"contentType":"image","value":{"src":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/4/8e7cc4102d6c11e9aa979329348d4c3e/Untitleddesign61-1615263931094.png"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Throughout my career, I have realised that most people are uncomfortable around intelligent and good-looking women. Women may not always get the opportunity to talk amidst their male counterparts. I have personally been to meetings where men would not converse with me, but chose to speak to my male colleagues. All my capabilities and qualifications seem to fade away. It is tough. Another example is office off sites. They have a disproportionate gender split. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"At such times, should women opt out due to lack of comfort? In a similar scenario, what would a man do?"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":" If women can get their views and opinions heard, they'd do well to break the gender stereotype. I have noticed that good work speaks for itself. This needed a lot of patience, acceptance and focus. It is important to stay calm and driven, despite the odds.\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true,"italic":true},"data":"Zohra Hajiani, Managing Partner - Validus Wealth "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Consistent hard work pays off \n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"The initial four-five years were challenging where I faced a lot of pushback as the men around me were only used to seeing women as secretaries or admin staff - deferring to the male supremacy. When I challenged it, wanting to be an equal, I was not taken seriously - clients would not shake hands with me or make eye contact while peers and seniors would not invest in training me as they felt I would not have the staying power for this business. Of course, there were tasks like fetching pizzas, coffee, inventory management, all that they thought were ‘better designed’ for a woman. I faced the objectification even more intensely during road shows where it was an all-men’s crowd and I couldn’t take my grievances to an authority.\n\nHowever, the happy twist in the story is that I kept going and did whatever it took to stay in the playing field. I volunteered more than I could do and even when I was not assigned on the particular project. I worked extra hours and I remember when I was seconded to London, I would literally go below my desk and sleep there. All I had was my toothbrush! Every opportunity I got, I took it. Because I knew the only way that I could make myself indispensable was by being better than all the guys – not just being as good, but being better. I had to show I was more committed, especially after I was married. I had to prove to them that I could do this. The consistent hard work paid off.\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true,"italic":true},"data":"Manisha Girotra, CEO - Moelis India"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"header":2},"data":"Changing attitudes\n"}},{"contentType":"image","value":{"src":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/4/8e7cc4102d6c11e9aa979329348d4c3e/Untitleddesign64-1615357048494.png"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"\nAs a woman in the workplace there are always subtle covert biases that we have to face. Having been a working professional for almost three decades it is interesting to see how mindsets have evolved over the years. \n\nAs times are changing, attitudes are changing too and I am hopeful for seeing many more equal opportunities for women at the workplace, especially at leadership positions. \n\nBy being responsive, not reactive; by being strategic and not only tactical, and cultivating a wide set of advisors has helped my journey.\n\n"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"italic":true},"data":"Vandana Chopra, Head - Brand and Communications, KPMG India. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"He was able to do all of this with his own money and he credits MakeMyTrip and its "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"restricted stock units (RSU) policy "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"for making it all possible.\n"}},{"contentType":"image","value":{"src":"https://images.yourstory.com/cs/2/25e9e0e0605211e984534d4121ad4bb6/image2-1615202696956.png","caption":"\u003cp>\u003cem>Jasmeet's BMW 3 Series M Sport\u003c/em>\u003c/p>"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“We are one of the few organisations where employees can create wealth from RSUs, apart from their annual earnings. Directors and above are offered a four-year plan, where stocks are divided into Restricted Stock Units (RSUs) and Performance Stock Units (PSUs). “"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"75 per cent of the stocks are RSUs that are vested equally over a period of four years and the rest are bucketed under PSUs and are vested for three years. "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":"Associate Directors and below are offered a four-year-program where 10 per cent of the stocks are vested in the first year, 20 per cent in the second year, 30 per cent in the third year and the 40 per cent in the fourth year,” Yuvaraj adds. \nIn terms of the allocation, "}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{"bold":true},"data":"stocks are granted to all employees at senior management levels, while mid-management roles are allotted shares based on performance"}},{"contentType":"text","value":{"formats":{},"data":". That’s how it has always been for this stuntwoman, who faced the vagaries of life at every turn, to become a winner.\n\nShe plays with fire, does deep-sea diving, performs dangerous stunts on cars and bikes, and yet says she wears her small injuries like awards. There was no choice for me. I never thought of taking this profession. It just came to me at the right time. There was a time in my life when I desperately needed work and money for myself and to support my family. I didn’t have a proper higher education, so I took what life gave to me,” she says.\n\nGeeta’s children were too young when she started the job. She says it was heart-wrenching for her to lock them up at home and go to work as there was no one to look after them.\n\nHer first stunt assignment was in Ladakh, which involved her being set on fire. \n"}},{"contentType":"blockquote","value":{"formats":{},"data":"“As my burns healed, so did my spirit. Women have been struggling to make a mark for ourselves in the society for ages, so what are these little dangers in front of all of that? Nothing! My real fear is what if I don’t have the job that I have today! There is no point in fearing anything. Forget your fears and move forward. We can do anything,” she says.\n\nBeing a male-dominated field, there were many people who doubted her capability of performing stunts.
